campaign.story:
IKAWA is revolutionising the way we roast and drink coffee with the world’s first digital micro-roaster.
Unlock a world of fantastic flavours and beautiful aromas by roasting your own coffee at home in minutes! 
However you like your coffee whether it’s a dark espresso or a light filter roast it comes from ‘green’ unroasted coffee beans. To get the perfect coffee you need the best green beans and the ideal roast tailored to those beans. 
The IKAWA Home Roaster enables you to roast your coffee at the push of a button. We offer a range of top quality green coffee beans from iconic locations, and provide roast recipes to bring the best flavours out of the beans. 
Brew your coffee how you like: Cafetière, Pour-over, Espresso, AeroPress, Moka pot or Filter, the IKAWA Home Roaster will take your connoisseurship to the next level – simply select the roast recipe on your smartphone, drop the beans into the roaster and watch them roast – it will take between 3 – 10 minutes. 
Then if you’re feeling adventurous, adjust recipe to create your own perfect roast: change roast duration, temperature and even the air flow with your smartphone or tablet to open up a world of flavours. 
As well as selling home coffee roasters our aim is to set up a supply chain where we can source excellent coffee from producers and sell it more directly to consumers. As selling green coffee simplifies the supply chain we will re-invest 10% of the revenue from selling green coffee back into projects that help farmers produce better quality coffee and earn more money.

How our home roaster makes your coffee perfect
1. Roast your coffee like a professional: IKAWA Coffee is supplied with a recommended roast recipe, each recipe perfectly tailored to bring out the best flavours of different coffee beans. The IKAWA Home Roaster will work with any green coffee, not just the beans we supply.
2. Fully customisable roast recipes: Get adventurous! You can adapt IKAWA's recommended roasting recipes or create a new one from scratch. See video "Product Development and Key Design Features" in the "More technical detail" section.
3. Share Roast Recipes: Share roast recipes with a community of coffee lovers using Facebook, Twitter and the IKAWA forum.
4. Sleek addition to your kitchen: Designed to fit into a modern kitchen, the roaster has a small footprint – similar to that of a kettle. It's made from top quality materials and will weigh approximately 4.3kg / 9.5 lbs.
5. Available Worldwide: IKAWA Home Roaster models are designed for all international power supplies. There will be the option for 220 – 240V roaster (as used in UK, Europe, China, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, Australia and most countries!), 110 – 120V versions (for North America, Central America, Venezuela Taiwan amongst others, and even a 100V Home Roaster for Japan. There will be a small shipping cost of £25 for European Union countries, and FREE shipping to Rest of World. We cover VAT for European Union countries, but not for other countries where local taxes and duty may vary.
 6. iOS and Android compatible: The IKAWA Home App will work with both iOS and Android. Other operating systems (such as Windows and BlackBerry) may be considered as Stretch Goals - please contact us at info@ikawacoffee.com to register interest. 
Featured by...
Revolutionising coffee  
Thanks to our invention, you can now choose green, unroasted coffee beans from iconic coffee origins and discover your perfect way to roast them. 
Unroasted Green coffee stays fresh for much longer, which means, you can now make a truly freshly roasted cup of coffee, using beans sourced directly from producers. 
IKAWA enables this win-win situation and new dimension to direct trade. Coffee drinkers receive excellent quality green coffee beans and can roast them how they want, and coffee producers get reinvestment to help improve coffee quality which will generate more income.
IKAWA will re-invest 10% of profits into coffee quality improvement projects led by the Cafédirect Producers' Foundation (CPF) in Africa and Latin America. CPF will also distribute micro-roasters funded via our £20 reward scheme. Roasters will be used to support smallholder farmers test and learn more about the quality of their own coffee – something they very rarely have the opportunity to do. CPF works with a network of 280,000 smallholder farmers globally, which makes them an ideal partner to achieve a greater impact, rather than setting up our own distribution scheme. This also means we can focus our energy on delivering the first batch of Home Roasters to our backers!
Our Story
IKAWA inventor Andrew grew up in developing countries where his dad worked with coffee farmers. It was this experience that gave him the idea for the micro-roaster, which he designed while studying at the Royal College of Art in London 6 years ago. IKAWA has gone on to be a finalist for Best New Product at Speciality Coffee Association of Europe (SCAE) 2012 for the first Professional Roaster and was finalist in Business Global Social Venture Competition of Berkeley University in 2011.  
Andrew, together with co-founder Rombout Frieling, made hundreds working prototypes before launching the IKAWA Pro Roaster, which is now used every day by leading coffee professionals all over the world.  
Some of the hundreds of prototypes we've created
The real challenge was to build a machine that could reproduce a roast accurately, regardless of the environment.
IKAWA has unique patented roasting technology and uses top quality components. During the roast process a papery skin comes off the coffee – called chaff. Over time this would block a normal filter – so we included a cyclone that will never get blocked. Our roasting system is patented with support from James Dyson. 
IKAWA has built a strong team fuelled by constant supply of freshly roasted coffee who are super excited to be launching the Home Roaster.
More Technical Detail
We thought you might like to know a bit more depth about the design process, and how some of the key features work so made this short video.
 Below are some of the aspects of the roaster we're most proud of: 
There is only one moving part in the whole roaster which is the fan. It is part of our patented roasting technology. The fan can reach a max speed of 22,500 RPM and achieves a number of critical features: 
Fan delivers heat from heating element to the roast chamber where coffee roasting happens 
The fan removes the chaff that’s released during roasting and sends it to the collection jar. The chaff will never block the roaster and affect air pressure and does not need external venting. 
After the roast, the fan blows the roasted coffee beans from the roast chamber into the collection jar. (see above video)
The case is super strong. It will be made from extruded Aluminium 6060-T6 and is 3.5mm think. Internal parts or the roaster are thermally isolated from the roasting components which can reach 240 degrees Centigrade. This means the roaster is safe to touch, even after a long roast. 
The roaster is able to very accurately follow the roast recipe – so if you program the same recipe, you will achieve the exact same results. This is due to accurate closed circuit temperature control and small quanity of coffee. We use a PT1000 (grade A) temperature sensor made from platinum which is ultra sensitive and stable. A PID Controller controls the amount of heat that the heating element produces using a PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) technique. So when you follow the app during a roast, you’ll see how closely the actual temperature matches the roast recipe. 
The Home Roaster is small and compact. It will not take over your kitchen and will not produce loads of smoke.
The Doser is on top of the roaster and is used to measure the perfect amount of coffee. Each roast takes 60g of green coffee which translates to around 50g of roasted coffee. It’s super simple to use and made from investment cast stainless steel. (see above video)
The lid is attached using sanarium-cobalt magnets which eliminates the need for screwing and makes it easy to clean. The lid is made from toughened safety glass similar to an oven door, it's transparent so can see the coffee as it roasts. 

Strength, Safety and Durability  
It will take 8 months from a successful Kickstarter project to deliver the Home Roasters. A considerable amount of time will be spent on testing the machine to ensure it is safe and works perfectly. 
All roasters are CE marked. Roasters sold to North America will also be UL Certified.  
Below are the 15 tests we undertake.
Repeatable Roast Test  
Air-flow programming test 
Hot Electronics Test 
1200 roast cycle durability test 
External Safety Assessment 
Surface Temperature Test
Blow-over test 
Extreme Roast test 
Single Fault Analysis 
Heating Element Failure Test  
Firmware / Software function test 
Consistent roast test 
Packaging drop-test 
Bluetooth communication test 
Electromagnetic compatibility test
Stretch Goals
We're delighted to meet our goal and want to give something back through our stretch goals, without complicating the project delivery. 
Rewards
Through this Kickstarter project we aim to raise enough money to pay for our first production run of the IKAWA Home Roasters. You can help us achieve this through backing our campaign.
Project Scope and Timeline 
We’ve taken this idea a long way already; built a network of suppliers, and created an award winning professional roaster. We know what it takes to deliver projects successfully and have well developed plans in place for the Home Roaster we’re launching on Kickstarter.
Backing from Kickstarter will enable us to: 
Finalise the new Home Roaster design. We need create a new simplified design that is straight forward to assemble at scale with a lower cost price
Invest in production tooling to reduce the manufacturing costs of the components. 
Develop an Apple and Android App for the Home Roaster. 
The Money we raise through Kickstarter will be spent on the following: 
Buying the stock to make the rewards. 
Electronic design work to re-package the electronics onto a single printed circuit board. 
Prototyping and testing to make sure the Home Roaster works perfectly every time. 
App programming to develop the new Home Roaster App. 
Travel costs to see our suppliers and Engineering partners. 
UL and CE Certification Testing to ensure that the Home Roaster is completely safe to use.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
In order to make the Home Roaster more affordable than the Professional Roaster we are having to evolve our designs and produce the roasters in larger production runs. There is always some degree of uncertainty when creating any new product, but we have taken every precaution to avoid this causing disruption and have extremely advanced plans already. 

We have the benefit of a strong network of manufacturing partners and the experience of several production runs of the Pro Roaster so have learnt a lot about the best ways to plan and produce IKAWA Roasters. Similarly, we have a global warehouse network set-up already which will help us to deliver the roasters to your door. 

We have been realistic with our timings, allowing a reasonable amount of time for each step of the production process. 

Please see Q&A section for any questions you may have, or if they’re not covered, drop us a line through Kickstarter or to info@ikawacoffee.com and we’ll be happy to help.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
First up, we’re pleased to report that we’ve been making steady progress dispatching Home Coffee Roasters and packs of coffee to Kickstarter backers, and it’s been rewarding to hear your feedback. Super exciting that this weekend, there will be hundreds of roasts on IKAWA Home Coffee Roasters around the world. 
This update is for those who’ve not received their roaster yet. Back in June in our last update we explained about a few of the specific shipping requirements for certain countries that meant orders hadn’t been dispatched.

June has been a bit of a whirlwind, since starting shipments we’ve already been receiving feedback both on the Comments section of Kickstarter, via email to Sam who’s manning the support@ikawacoffee.com email, and via social media. Thanks for all the feedback - we’re pleased that you’ve now stated to receive your roasters, and put them into action…
There have also been some comments / questions about our Shipping Schedule, with backers eager to find out when their roasters will arrive. We set out in May that we’re planning to ship on ‘first come first served’ approach, but also factoring in which backers have provided shipping information, and any other shipping constraints etc.

Things are coming together nicely at IKAWA HQ this week and we're on track for the first shipments next week. 
In the meantime, we wanted to share this shot film with you - it's a sneak peak at the IKAWA At Home roaster, coffee and app, and is designed to help you set it up simply and enjoy your first roast.

updates.update_userinfo: Home Coffee Roaster Backers >> Kickstarter Survey.
updates.update_content:
Thank you for your swift replies to the email we sent out last week. 
We're working through your addresses and entering them into our system, to build the shipping plans as set out here.
For anyone who has not yet completed their shipping info and voltage requirements, please look through your inbox for an email from support@ikawacoffee.com with the subject "Your IKAWA Home Coffee Roaster from Kickstarter - Shipping and Product Information Request".

updates.update_userinfo: Home Coffee Roaster Backers >> Complete Your Shipping Info...
updates.update_content:
Quick note to let you know we've sent the email to backers of the Home Coffee Roaster - with and without the green coffee, inviting you to complete your shipping details and key information to allow us to plan the shipping schedule. 
Please look out for the email from IKAWA Coffee - from the support@ikawacoffee.com email address, with subject line: "Your IKAWA Home Coffee Roaster from Kickstarter - Shipping and Product Information Request".

Greetings, and apologies for missing the April update – we’ve been working hard get everything ready to start the first shipments in May.
Since the last update, we’ve made some great progress with our first production run of 230v roasters, and are now working on the next batch – so we have a limited number of the very first IKAWA Home Coffee Roasters in stock.

This is the Kickstarter update we wanted to post last month, but needed to cross a few T’s and dot some more lower-case j’s before posting it to Kickstarter.
We’re excited to say that after months and months of testing, fine tuning and further testing, we’re now at a point where we have signed off on our final roaster design, hired two more Production Technicians taking the team to four to increase our capacity, have all the components in stock at our workshop, and last Friday we set up our workshop to start production for real.

We've had a really busy month, loads of progress to report, and encouraging results from our first stages of testing. 
We were hoping that by the end of this week (and it's Friday afternoon now), we'd be able  to share some more concrete results from our testing, but we're not quite there yet. 
So here's very brief update.

Happy New Year to you all – if its not too late to say that? 
We’ve started the year in fifth gear and have a lot to report this month already. 
In our updates we try to share the progress we make (and challenges we face) each month, and the work that goes on behind it - this month is no exception. All this work is trying to get to one place – the first ever IKAWA Home Coffee Roasters arriving to your kitchens, and meeting and exceeding your expectations.

Season’s Greetings to you all from the team at IKAWA.  
Before we shut down the office for a few days to take stock, recharge and prepare for an exciting start to 2017, we wanted to break from ‘tradition’ of our monthly updates, and focus today on coffee – as that’s ultimately what it’s all about!

comments.content: @Ikawa, thank you so much ; )
@Ikawa, please an update for contributors who have not yet received their Ikawa machine would be greatly appreciated, do not forget us : )
@Ikawa, any news about shipping to Canada? ; )
@Ikawa - I totally dig them, great blogs, keep them coming :D
I hope everyone is moving there now ... right? :)
@everyone I shall no longer be making posts here at this kickstarter funding page. I hope to see you at our new home!

The type of tobacco was a clear pipe tobacco, it wasn't distinct enough for a strain or brand. Simply just the essence and aroma of fresh wet pipe tobacco. As for finding that sweet spot in the dark, I can only say that I recommend getting a lot of just one bean from a known region and variety that does well in that sector and roast until you've found it. In my case I chose a Sumatran.
What type of tobacco flavours did you get? I din't think that you roasted dark, and the type I'm looking for only occurs dark.

So to return to the point of why I take this bean into that sector of the roast; the answer is that it is only at its best when dark roasted.And if I want a dark element in my coffees, then I need beans that suit that sector of roasting. Dark medium may be OK(ish), but it is much better dark. But only if the profile is right. And, at the moment, I'm not sure that the Ikawa has the ability to make the most of these beans. I've never spent as long trying to coax these flavours out of these beans with any other roaster. I can get pretty much any of the lighter/brighter flavours out (obviously with different beans), can vary body and mouthfeel, but quality at the dark end is still eluding me.

@mike, I forgot to mention I have got tobacco flavors, it was either by luck of the brew or the roast but I think that flavor (and I feel bad for saying so) is an inherent quality of the bean. I say this because I have been trying to maximize a chocolate note I have been getting off the cup. Trying to either accent/ amplify or move the flavor more to the front of the palate or taste sequence and I can't so far. Only 10 roasts left so wish me luck.

@Mike I fully understand where you are coming from, however my own attempts (and limitations of the points, which I am finding more and more absurd to have a "precision roaster" and then severely limit the users capabilities and information feedback by creating so may restrictions on the app @ikawa)) have found that a spike in the roast has not yielded a positive result. When looking at other aspects in life it does not make sense either, scientifically speaking . Though I would be happy to be proven wrong. At 22% weight loss is even past what Starbucks gives in their dark roast or close too. And would also question why you are using such expensive beans to play in that sector of roast? Surely you can see the reason for questioning, and not as any sort of jab or wag of the finger.

I've had nil success so far in achieving leather or tobacco notes, and that has never been a problem for me before on any roaster. Smoky is the closest I've got, but that's not the same thing at all. You have to have the right beans of course ('tobacco' pretty much only found in aged coffees) and you have to take them dark enough to bring those flavours out, but I would be very interested in the profiles and beans if anyone else has achieved those notes on the Ikawa.
The good thing is having got interesting flavours. The next step is to identify them and then devise/revise a profile to bring out what you like most in what you detect.

Regarding the best time for espresso ... my experience is that the peak of quality of most origins is at 2 - 5 days ...only some special cases seam to be getting to their best after resting for more than a week. And my usual approach is to start drinking it before that peak, usually day after roast, so that i dont miss it. From my experience there is very much happening in the taste profile during that first week ...

If my memory serves me right my Millard ramp (4th segment?) is like 21.7*F/min and you should play in that sandbox if you want to manipulate flavor but like I said we are not Sith. Varying the dip in the fan ramp to where you think 1st will be around. In my opinion at that set of variables, it is the decrease in fan speed that is the speed into first. Drop time for me usually happens after I roast a profile and note timings, especially during this phase, the aroma changes. I still cannot say yet of when the best time to drop (def before you loose the aroma it gives off).

@Pavel, hey glad you like it. You are a brave man if you are pulling espresso strait after a roast ;) I suggest after grinding let the beans rest for around 20 mins and that should help, but nothing can be a substitute for rest. Earlier I've said that 9 days rest was good but now I feel somewhere around 3-5 might actually be better. But the best way still remains up to your palate and preferences.

I also tried the Nitro flush and made espresso of Devens profile right when It cooled down. It really works, no gusher, rather a slow shot actually (i overdosed a bit in fear of a gusher). Very interesting taste .. bit fizzi but overall very interesting to taste so very fresh beans as espresso

@Deven @Mike .. I had tried both profiles today, on pretty problematic yet quite expensive rwanda, and I have to say both are really interesting. I really like Devens profile, though I should probably stopped it a bit sooner (did not spot it before its end) ... Mikes spike version I did have to stop quite sooner, it also cracked sooner and the beans also look darker, so I should have stopped it even sooner than I did. But really interesting to try those and see how it goes ... :)))

Can you take a picture of the cut bean? Those numbers are astounding especially if there is no defect, scorching, facing, tipping, dry distillate/grainy texture, flat and dry/baked. Link the profile. Especially using the same profile for a peaberry vs a malabar which not only are different varietals, densities, surface area and processing. What does that peaberrytasteelike?
Exactly the same profile as the MM. Roasted darker than MM because the MM takes more roasting.
Yes I agree there are no absolutes, we are not Sith. And malabar/robusta is its own thing.
17.5% weight loss.
The point really is that there are no absolutes, much depends on the bean type and how it was then processed and any later treatment.
Your scale might need to recalibrate. I'm not sure but 25% is like making me scratch my head. I'm not saying anything to be negative...just it's rather quite astonishing.

At 25% you are losing a lot more than just moisture. That is just too much, I highly doubt any origin would be left. It would be interesting to see what the bean looks like if you can take a pic and post it.
I've just done one, on a different profile, that's down 26%. And nowhere near black.

Fan speed alternates the nature of the roaster. The faster the fan is the more the roaster is in the realm of convective heat. The lower the fan speed the more the beans are being roasted in conductive heat. I have a lot more to say on that subject but will keep brevity key right now. 16% weight loss is almost the end of the spectrum, one would hear of Spanish roasts being around 18%. I shot for 13% but am still hitting around 14-15%. Ending color and roast degree are two different things. Like two eyes trying to focus on the same image. They need to meet in the middle so the beans are roasted enough on the inside and look like the roasted from the outside. Outside and inside color need to match(usually) without internal scourging or a "smoked brisket" ring on the inside. After a roast take a bean or two and a sharp knife and cut through the bean on your cutting board, and look at the inside vs outside in a good light, use a sharp knife and be consistent with the light you use. Nothing is better than sunlight. For the nature of the air roaster and given that 2mins are allowed in the range of combustion, one can achieve virtually as dark as you like. No offense: if you are drinking your coffee with additives either the beans aren't good or your roast isn't. If you get an upset stomach or the taste is too strong (astringent) then your are roasting way too far killing off any flavors by turning them bitter or astringent or "roasty/ashy are also notes of overdevelopment. Excluding health problems or you just like that. As I am in the camp of buying 5lbs of one bean (yes it does get boring in some sense but also a sprinkle of achieve is in there too) I've taken my 11:50 roast down to 8:42 with the same results. The smaller the roaster and bean mass are the shorter the roast time (to an extent). Especially an air/fluid bed are much faster at roasting than other roasters.
PS I do have a similar 12 minute profile taking beans to a lighter level. Better for some beans, but doesn't bring out quite the range of flavours that this one does.

I hope so. My guess is that the bean mass temperature is still rising, but slowly. A lower, but still substantial, amount of extra heat going into a bean mass already well into a roasting temperature.

I see the time as simply one of the factors, as in all cooking. You can cook hotter for shorter or lower for longer. The results are not the same, although they would both be equally 'done'. I'd really like scope to go longer than 12 minutes because I find the 12 minutes a limit that reduces some of the flexibility I'd like to test out.
Personally I will always go on taste, and I see the fan speed as simply an alternative way of managing the temperature of the beans. I notice that it seems to be a major way of doing so on the Pro.

The fan level is set to produce a low number of spinners but with confidence that the beans will be moving across a wide range of beans. Sometimes too many spinners but that is a smaller issue than the beans not moving and me not realising it until later.

So Mike I was just wondering if you had done much experimentation on varying the fan speed whilst developing a profile; & if so what are your findings? Ultimately what is your reasoning/theory behind a high initial fan speed?
I have found that the ones I really like are different to the ones I would have expected from previous roasting experience.
@Mike :) well you have quite a neat amount to choose from. Very good for you ... (I am now on a similar numbers, but just because of those small samples I have still to test roast :))
There have been a fair number of beans where the outcome seemed to have no particular distinction. But I've not found another profile that was better for those beans either.
Grr @ tamping, I did mean having* :)
Now to roast...

@Deven... sure I understand the “soy sauce” flavour is not something one sort of expects to taste in the coffee, it just sounds really intersting to me. In the same way that I enjoy sometimes a coffee that I would not consider to be good, but still interesting and new taste for me ... and in the same way that I taste and usually drink even my not really perfect shots ;) (like todays 1+ minute long shot done on Kompresso, because I overdosed a bit too much - still intereting though a LOT overextracted one :D)
@Weiwei, have you tried emailing IKAWA, I feel for you. And selfishly would appreciate more Ikawan roasters discussing their experiences. Has anybody in Canada received their roasters yet?
@Ikawa ; ) any news for china shipping!?
Great to be learning such a tastefull skill, on such a good and cheap-to-make-mistakes roaster :))

But a contingency to getting a good development in brown is having a fast enough slope to get first crack but slow enough that I can smell the aroma developing. But how do you get a clear development to brown you ask? Well the yellow needs to be fully formed even and stretched enough. Ergo other parts of the profile effect other parts of the profile. Seems obvious but so often the things we are looking for are right in front of us. Still I have not fully flushed out all my theories. I'm not planning on drinking my failures like I said most stuff is failing and is transferred to my compost. I taste, make notes and carry on. I prefer chocolate but like most of us noobs, we are too early in the understand to apply preferences yet. The first coffee I tried this morning tastes like umami soy sauce bomb, it was not pleasant but made for a really good base for a soy sauce base for my chicken I just grilled :)

Yes I can agree on that (a forum) and I got an email reply from the creators that it is being worked on (not in those exact words). So far to understand a profile it breaks down into quite a few things but I'll be brief. Charge temp, getting pale, length of pale to yellow, stretching and forming yellow to a nice gold (theory), ripping through brown (or not), figuring out momentum from brown into first crack, slowing down enough to get a clear first crack phase then a gap and then second crack. I stress understanding getting a clear first and second crack because those really help you find an ending temp at whatever point you want to drop. Others parts of the profile effect other parts of the profile. I believe that the main part of development takes place during brown and not after first crack due to the attributes of the roaster.

Sure, I understand that. And as I said, I have lots of green beans to roast now (did get a go on some Nordic approach Rwanda, but the first batch was really far from being good results, so I will do some more experiments this weekend) ... its just that, though I might be able to load your profile and test it on my beans, it would not tell me much really. Maybe if at least the origin and type of the bean is simillar it could be done, but maybe it looks we would need some other way how to share our progress, not just the profiles. I hope the forum will be open soon ... its needed for sure ...

I guess you'll have to do research on where to buy from in the meantime. For me prob shipping alone would cancel IKAWA out from being a good coffee source for me like in the case of sweet Maria's is to you. Hence why I suggested getting on coffee forum and that gets most people started/informed/connected easy enough. For example some people also do a coffee coop or a group buy with other people nearby.though it's usually with people you trust and kno.

So, not sure if Ikawa could be willing to provide something like that for us, maybe we could also use some beans shops like sweetmarias, but a few kg flying around the world are really not the best way to buy i guess.
https://www.home-barista.com/home-roasting/how-to-measure-length-of-time-of-first-crack-t32285.html

@christo I wholeheartedly do not recommend buying greens off of eBay. Ebay is a company. And that is all I'll say about them but I've learned from trying to procure Chinese tea amongst other things. That finding a trustable and reliable sources on eBay is...certainly doable. However finding a "local" coffee shop that's willing to sell you greens is easy. By local I mean within easy/cheap shipping (for me in the use that's usually around $9). I pay 6/lb greens very drinkable cups not lacking but not so easy you can throw some heat at it and it tastes good. I also have an issue saying IKAWA beans were "decent quality". Those beans were impeccable. For the price. That is what that should look like. However coming from glimpsing the light at the end of the tunnel, understanding how coffee is roasted and how this roaster can achieve that underlie all the problems and solutions.
I might retry some of my discarded profiles with the beans I know are good to see how much that goodness is down to the profile. Will also need to recheck my records for the better beans.
Having played around a bit with 12 minute roasts, I'll start going shorter again next. Might work better for the beans I've not been keen on so far. And maybe improve those I like.
I would love for some roasters to start developing profiles though. I've 'bean' a huge fan of Hasbean for quite a few years now, so I'm looking at you Steve! Please?

I'm not sure I have the ability to persuade any roaster to develop Ikawa profiles, but would certainly like it if they did. The Ikawa ones don't help much because they are clearly designed around very different taste preference.

But - I wanted to say something else. I highly recomend getting friendly with some your smaller local roaster, showing him ikawa and what it can do .... it might have some beneficial outcomes ;) being able to make 10 different roast samples from half a kg can be really strong point :))

For many what I am about to say won't be anything new; From my limited roasting experience, I would certainly feel that I have achieved better flavours/experiences more easily from the Ikawa greens. Going cheap to learn about roasting might seem like a good idea, but I feel the actual success of roasts to be less satisfying & so understandably this is some what counterintuitive. Since owning the Ikawa I have learnt a lot more about coffee & I don't think I'll buy anything again without grading or any specifics about the green origins. Hopefully I'll find a happy medium towards price & quality somewhere :)

@Christo hey the great to hear I'm not talking into a void. Lol. I'm sure a lot of the profiles will be similar in a way, that said I have no idea. I've only got glimpses of a good roast I'm sure it'll still take me the next 35 chances to get a better insight. Was that Colombian from a high altitude? Did you try a profile with a lower temp charge?

Anyway I have just noticed the time & this was only meant to be a quick post! I do tend to waffle on and right now I should really be sleeping as I really don't feel too great. I hope this isn't the start of that dreaded 'Oz' flu that is apparently going to strike the UK this winter.... Goodnight.

Yea it might be for the huehue, after a couple days of rest it is not giving me anything as good as when I tasted the bean after the roast, I'll do another batch of this and see what it tastes like in the cup immediately and after 7 days. However to the credit of the hardware and design of the roaster I tried a Sumatra peaberry that is crystal clear and tastes like strawberry pop tarts. The difficult part is remembering. What profile I used on it.

And yes - as you say, I am also not thinking of fiddling too much with rather expensive Ikawa beans, thats why I said it would be great to have some cheaper material to share our different methods and taste the outcome of each others profiles :)
But I am still learning and I need 86pt beans that I can practice turning from green to brown and not feeling bad that I'm making fertilizer for my plants.
I would love to taste the results of this curve and understand better what it means ;)

So today I was able to roast a lot, a whole 6 roasts slightly tweaking the profile, this time only changing the variables of what one would called "development time" or the last part of the roast. Changing when that part starts and for how long and at what temp and slope. So working with just these 4 variables I was able to roast this Huehuetenango to taste slightly sweet, a very interesting acid that I can place and finishes with an aftertaste of a fresh Dan cong oolong. I am going to wait til the next day or two to brew these different roasts and see how it all worked out. The profile is my favorite that had a great bean taste.
https://share.ikawa.support/profile_home/?CAESEGFy5YBX0ElIkSHF68+kabwaC0EgNTE0IDExOjQwIgUIABD0AyIGCLkDEMoLIgYIqhIQhw0iBgjCFhDwDyIGCLwrEIAUIgYI0zYQ8xQqBQgAEO0BKgYI3CQQvQEqBgjTNhDLATABOgYI20QQqQE=

The roast you gave, I feel, uses an exhaust temp profile. Which a denser (Ethiopian) bean has little problems with the initial surge in heat and as long as you roast for the right duration things seem to be drinkable. Have you noticed a difference from a cool roaster to one that's been preheated with previous roasts?

I am also not using beans from Ikawa. In part because I'm following the premise that: you don't learn to drive on a race car. I am using less expensive beans that require sorting still. And trying drastically different profiles. One main thing I have come to realize is that this roaster (when it comes to cracks) is very temp dependent. Besides warming up the roasting there seems to be very low conductive heat and almost no radial heat.

As you say the window of acceptability is quite wide. Hoos also wrote in his treaties similar observations and really leaves it to the roast to decide what they like to produce rather than a dogmatic "you must do this", and I agree. His book was mainly about the next step, as in, you are getting these flavors 1) do you like it? 2) these variables will lean/move the taste profile to one side or another. I also have found this to be true; similar tastes and bean roast result from similar profiles just slightly varied on how the profile is changed and I've found similar origin and variety will also be similar.

Ok cool yea I do also chew on my beans and I don't mean to harp on about cupping but it just gives more info and that's the last I'll mention it here. Your curve looks like a set I've tried and had some for data collected. It's all still a lot of nuances to understand about roasting in general and this roaster. That is awesome that you were able to get a full first crack and development.

https://share.ikawa.support/profile_home/?CAESEH/NC02kYk5io5Pcet9XdWUaDFRlc3Rwcm9maWxlMiIFCAAQ9AMiBgiwAxDGDyIGCLsHEJkTIgYI6gsQ/hEiBgjyDxCXEyIGCKUqEKsSKgUIABC0ASoGCKUqEJ4BMAE6Bgj9LxDYAQ==https://share.ikawa.support/profile_home/?CAESEH/NC02kYk5io5Pcet9XdWUaDFRlc3Rwcm9maWxlMiIFCAAQ9AMiBgiwAxDGDyIGCLsHEJkTIgYI6gsQ/hEiBgjyDxCXEyIGCKUqEKsSKgUIABC0ASoGCKUqEJ4BMAE6Bgj9LxDYAQ==

There is a reason why cupping is the way everyone in the coffee world "tastes" coffee not just because it's pretty easy. I think you are really missing out if you are not. I've been v60'n almost every day at least once a day since 2008 and I do cuppings because it minimizes other variables and gives a really nice clarity of how you roasted. 8.25g per 150mL @200*F soaking in a cup no straining for 4 minutes.

Well..... the curve/temps/rates/derivatives aka speed/slope are all factors that contribute to what's in your beans to be developed as well as I am interested to see people's fan speed. I have been playing around with the fan in my latest roasting. When you are in the IKAWA app looking at a profile on the bottoms right is a "share" button select that and there are various options. You can copy and past the profile here (it will be a link). If you scroll down through the comments you can see some previous curves posted already.

@Deven - I could share the curve later today, but I do not think its matters too much ... I was asking if you might have a simillar observation or if its just me being surprised the development after first crack is nice and slow :). So, if you would like to really see just let me know, I will find a way how to share it. And - yes, I always do taste the bean right after roast. Picking some average size average colour bean and chewing on it, looking for a signs of underdevelopment or maybe also overdevelopment :) but that I have to see yet ... I usually stop 30s - 2 minutes after the last audible pop of a first crack, so ... Then I usually let it rest for like day or two and then we run through it on espresso. I tend to not to do cupping, because it is not too important for me to have it that repeatable, I just want to know how it tastes as espresso, and V60 :D
@ikawa any news for Hong Kong shipping? We take all standards, US UK Aus. I didn't get update email from you guys.

@pavel it is hard to analyze your roast without seeing your curve. Maybe you lost your momentum after first and so the beans didn't develop further. Maybe roast length is instead affecting your rest time. Are you literally tasting a bean or doing a cupping?

@Ikawa - I have a special question :) because we had two alternatives and I used the account on Ikawa to do the survey, kickstarter shows me all the time I have yet to fill the survey here. What should I do to get rid of it and not cause any confusions? :)

@Christo Faulds - well I am still far away from needing to clean anything else than the glass top, but I also see how it builds a bit on other parts, so, some recomendations from those who had to do that allready would be great :D.

I had noticed something interesting, and would like to ask if you have similar observations. While doing some samples of another natural ethiopia guji, I did a first roast, which had a crack starting at 4:10, last pop of first crack at 5:14, and I stopped the roast manually at 6:30 (decreasing temperature curve after cca 2:30 or so but that is not too important). I tasted a bean and though I will do another roast some 30 - 60s longer. I did end it at 7:30, tasted a bean and though it looked a bit darker it did not taste that much different, so I went for another roast that I ended at 8:30. Today we went through them all, and they were really not TOO different as I would expect, from adding so much time after first crack. Its seems positive for me and others who like to have lighter roasts, as it really looks like the window of an acceptable result is really wide, after it gets out of the underdeveloped state, but at the same time I can now understand now a bit more why those that wanted to have dark roast may have a harder time to tuning it to their liking from the base roasts.

@Christo-Faulds. I have been wondering about the long term need for a cleaning regime, but not to the point of thinking of doing anything. Drum roasters tend to get pretty grubby over time, so I'm comfortable with this for now; remarkably clean really given the number of roasts it has done.

Up to this point I have come to the conclusion its probably more trouble than worth and best left alone. Has anyone else had the desire to try and clean anything else other than the lid or is it JUST me? :)
Merci ; ) @Ikawa
@Ikawa ; ) any news for Canada shipping!?

In other news, I just finished a roast that I immediately brewed via V60 it is bitter and I'm happy about it because I feel most of my roasts lately have been underdeveloped and the mesquite wood has been a plague. So to get an overdeveloped cup has been a nice change. Juggling charge temp, spacing a good transition from yellow to brown and finding a nice ramp to first crack and grasping a nice development time has been and still is a work in progress..
A good read for those who want to hear what Hoos says about thermocouples. Although obvious, it still helps keep things in perspective. And as someone who tinkers it gives fruit for thought.

I wanted to share some moderate success with you guys. I've tried this on a couple different beans and I have to say the real glimpse of the light is smelling the exhaust air during the fist past to the peak, I was getting some crazy fruit (tangerine, florals) but was not able to carry those notes through the roast as it changed from bag to hay and then to mesquite, mustard, sweet marshmallow vanilla. I don't know why but I seem to always get that last part even in a Guat and Indian. The last phase of the roast starts 1C about a 1/3rd in and finishes with second. As always, press the eject button when you see fit. In the cup I get nice chocolates, some Cinnabon spices and pleasant creaminess (3days reat). I wasn't able to try it fresh as I now am close to 1-2lbs of roasted coffee aging in my cabinet and my kitchen smells of the gods.

Unlike drum roasters I think the worry is scorching/tipping/chipping. Baking and stalling I would figure are the least of our worries as that really is caused from too long in the Millard stage (pre 1st crack 390*F to 400*F bean temp) I am having lots of trouble with tipping and scorching inside the bean, from what I've gathered, is cause from the rampant a charge temp and not enough grace on the curve from o-212*F and then beginning a 2 min dry up to 290*F +/- 10*

I think I'll be 6 months before being on top of it, but I have made considerable progress. I can pretty reliably target a darkness level with very different profiles. I can get decent coffee right through the range. But getting the most out of the beans is another matter. And I'm not sure about the actual ROR, so avoiding stalling/baking is a matter of trial and error.
PS I might switch my tasting to 10 days post roast. I'm finding noticeable improvement on most roasts.
Sorry I didn't see your post until now but I agree with you 100%, I hope I can figure this roaster out before 6 months, we'll see.

Also to note that the temp reading in drum roasters are mainly of bean temp and secondarily (but referred to less is the environmental temp). The ikawa does not read bean temp but air temp. Which is not a hindrance but doesn't do any favors either. More or less this is why I have been talking about "rubber banding" aka bean temp catching up to air temp, and finding the correlation between Hoos's temps and other drum roasters and relating it to the IKAWA. My 1C usually happens around 485*F-521*F depending on time and incline of the ramp (Sumatra). Because this air roaster is different from other air roasters there is a lot of uncharted territory. Pun definitely intended.

To start with "are we mimicking a drum?", I think we all are, from what I've gathered Sivetz (and air roasters that have publicized graphs) start the roast climbing to 500*F and then sustaining the heat with as close to a sustained temp as possible until the beans turn a certain color which don't yield great results. All the the people willing to share info/discussions I've been reading have to do with the drum roasters. I've concluded that I like home-barista the best, yes I've read most of the other forums and I've like home-barista since I was a barista :) as for a "bible" that's a pretty tough question. The back logs of HB forums are really good. I've previously stated The books by Hoos and Rao and William boot's "reflections on roasting fundamentals" also Mill City Roasting videos on YouTube is very thoughtful. I think after reading up and watching the videos is the first step, the second would be to learn about food, caramelize sugar, Millard some onions, bake bread or roast cacao. There are directional hints in lots of different areas but the best thing to do is to experiment on 5-10lbs of the same coffee. I just finished 5lbs of this Sumatra and I still am not satisfied and have not been able to answer all the questions I have been thinking of. Now I'll have to get at least 5 more lbs of another coffee and find my bearings again. The real bible will be all of our roast logs and posting of roast curves. I don't think I can stress enough of having a roast log and taking notes as that is the most empirical way of conducting these experiments and learning. I can't really comment on your timings and such because 1. I don't haven't a Columbia to roast 2. I don't feel confident in my understanding of this roaster yet. To those of us in Canada and China I hope you get your roaster soon!

@Mike completely agree with combining; not just blends.of different beans, but also different roasts of the same bean. That can most certainly be said after the dark brown soft sugar experience! The learning continues...

I have always found air and drum roasting very different and copying from one to another provides very limited benefits. Then again, I've always taken 6 months or so to become happy with a new system, so I'm not a very quick learner. I don't think that there's any necessary difference in the amount of heat in air and drum roasting. Beans react to a given heat input (and input profile) and both can achieve it on the same timescales. Air roasting is likely to be more even though.

But I'm not going to spend all my time drinking unrested roasts if I know that they are likely to be better later. My experience is that roasts peak between 3 and 21 days after roasting usually; lighter, brighter at the shorter end. You may find it different of course. I also always have a range of beans and a range of darknesses available because I nearly always prefer to drink a blend.

And remember that Rob is talking about exhaust temperatures whereas we have input. And neither is the bean mass temperature (ditto for all other roasters). Working out the ROR of the bean mass is really problematic.

...then the roast wasn't good altogether. That is interesting that your are similarly trying to mimic a drum roaster as I am as well. I feel that the air roaster because of the lack of the radiation and conduction heating or at least a severe decrease, that the roast temp is about 60-100*F difference than a drum. And I'm still trying to figure out if there is any rubber-banding/momentum but so far I would say there is very little because of the lack of the two heats mentioned before.

Personally I do a cupping between 12-24 hrs (not a cupping roast but with my regular roast) then with the same roast it only lasts anywhere from 3-4 days, usually less, and if the roast sucks I'll let it sit in the back but my roasting mistakes don't go away with more time. I'm sure if I had a 1 lb roaster I would go longer ... but learning on such a small batch my thinking goes like; if the roast isn't good enough in cupping and the next couple days

@Mike and Deven :) Hello again. Sorry for not responding, but I am in the middle of a large project at work .. so just work and a little bit of sleep with no time for anything else. So .... Not much roasting on my side lately. Regarding me not being able to enjoy dark roasts, its very much connected to that taste and smell that happens when you caramelize sugar and overdo and "burn" it a little bit. I am very sensitive to that and I do not like it at all ... and for me the start of this is way before you get anywhere near second crack. To me, this particular flavor obscures those floral and fruity and other light notes .. It might be quite different in blends, but I do not do blends, as I want to see the bean very cleanly and sharply how it is. I do not mind the gaps in the taste profiles, or high spikes at some places ... I enjoy it because of those differences. So that is very different from making a rich and ballanced blends where you most probably will try to have it all sort of covered and filled as a smooth hill of tastes. I am quite crazy about doing the exact opposite - using high quality grinders and precise sieves to make as straight and sharply defined extraction as I can - to have all those spikes and valleys sharply defined. :D

Maybe IKAWA can chime in and say what the differences are. By smell alone I found that ending temp for my Sumatra Mandheling Aceh organic from Sweet Maria's was 521*F/271*C. In cupping it was ok and I did get some molasses and sweet mesquite. However, I believe because the ROR was too steep it was vastly thin in body with no chocolate or a "Sumatra" flavor after resting and pulled as an espresso and V60, throughout a week. I am sure the right profile is there but it will take some time for me to find it. My theory really revolves around that sustaining a constant high temp will "evaporate" the flavor away. But finding the right drying time and smooth transitions while achieving FC+ at lower temps for darker profiles and properly developed light profiles will take some balancing between finding the right jump to temp in the beginning and also given the limited number of points, when to initiate a bounce in temp/phase change.

Have now tried both Ikawa roasts again (7 days after roast). Acid tones the same but somewhat more relaxed. Woodwind rather than brass. Don't get all the flavours they describe, but there are more varied flavours. Palatable. Still suspect that they would work better in espresso machine.

Resting isn't development, but the flavours do continue to change/develop for some time, and it's a mistake to draw firm conclusions before the optimum resting time, whatever that is. I've seen advice saying that beans are at their best 3+7 days after the roast, and other advice saying it's between 7 and 28 days. My own experience is that 7-10 days is often needed especially for darker roasts, though 3 should be OK for lighter ones.

Personally I think development should have been taken into consideration during the roast and not the "development" or the resting of the beans after the roast. Which is also very tricky considering the the cool down phase is just as significant as the other aspects of the roast yet unlike a typical drum, there is no drop but a gradual transition to a cooler temp which is where I think people are getting into trouble. I wish there was a forum up to discuss these things. Maybe I will start a thread on home-barista forum, please look for a tread maybe titled something like "Home of IKAWA"

@Christo-Faulds ... well, the moment you point out is when it goes from preheating (with higher air flow) to actuall roast (with arflow set in the curve) ... so the drop in airflow is caused by that. And ...yes at allmost did not move :) but it takes a few moments when they dry a bit and get lighter when they start moving reasonably. It happens with heavy beans, and not warmed up roaster ... so when you just switch it on and start with burundi you might see something simillar with the ikawa profile. As I wrote, i keep looking at th center of the swirl ... because I have seen roasts where the whole was rotating without any change in relative positions - (happened with ikawa burundi and not warmed up roaster) and that I think is really really bad ... but when they change positions in the middle and you see constant changes in which bean is in the middle I would think that is a reasonable minimal movement. At least from my limited understanding :D

And .. one more thing .. and I have to do this, because ...:) well ... you will understand. Today we tried my 5 different test roasts of Ethiopia Guji sundried natural, with a friend that is a skilled barista and professional roaster. I will post pictures and profiles and all a bit later for @Christo and all others .. but for now I can say this - the best roast of all was the one I based from one of the Ikawa Ethiopian profiles ... and the first one I stopped just by looking at the beans and smelling what comes out of the exhaust. It had crack starting at cca 4minutes and I ended the roast at 7 minutes, 1 and someting minutes after the crack ended. I made another one minute longer roast, and some other profiles that I wanted to see what effect they would have, all stopping by feel and look. All the other roasts were also good but though somehow not having the same great ballance in the cup. And even the worst one that did not crack audibly though I waited to 9th minute was quite drinkable, though not any close to best one. AND ... there is more. He said about the best roast, that he does not remember he had any coffee while at Budapest WOC that was as good as this one (which I can confirm too, because it was sooo aromatic and fruity and all ... really amazing coffee). Which means at least one thing - that Ikawa Home with really great quality beans, can produce a taste profile that can compete with professionally roasted SO coffee. I dont say a professional with professional equipment would not make it better (but I think it would not be and order of magnitude better, just a bit better ...because it was really great espresso), but - the tool we have now is not a toy, its a really good tool :D and that is what I expected but yet am delighted to be able to confirm. It could also mean few more things. One of those is that I think we are provided with a very good base in the 5 roast profiles we now have from Ikawa. Also I think (unless its just me being a sort of a genius roaster ... which I dont feel to be ...) it means its a very well readable and predictable tool (It was only like 8th coffee I roasted without premade profile, and a first one that I had enough of a sample to experiment around a bit more). It may also mean its not that easy to make a really bad roast, because even though I made a roast one minute longer than the best one, it was still very good espresso, just not as aromatic and fruity as the best one.

I would also add one thing I have learned from you at Budapest, and that is to turn IkawaHome on and leave it for some time to warm up. Though it is not visible or feels warm, it really helps to make the first roast the same as all the rest ...

@Roland - If you are roasting the Ikawa Ethiopians, the crack is allmost unnoticable. But I have to say roasting other coffee which crack in a normal way, you can hear it meters away. So its somethink with the roast profile that sort of muffles and hides the crack, or the beans themselve do not crack too loudly ... I dont know. But expect to hear much more noticable crack at some time :D And, as I said before - I think all that we are asking for will come. Just maybe a bit later because they might have hard time making the roasters fast enought to not leave some of us waiting too long ... so ... I totally agree that it is needed. I only said it might be good to use the time we are not having it to learn in a way that is also very good ... :D

I have posted a longer movie of the beans spinning in the roasting chamber and also a photo of the roaster with the top glass cover on my Instagram account. For those who have not received their Home Roaster yet, you can check them out. My Instagram name is rolandlmlim

For the first time in my life, I believe I have finally heard what 1st crack sounded like. I was doing my 6th roast, roasting some Ethiopia Yirgacheffe when I heard a faint "click" sound and then a lot of chaff suddenly came off and blown into the glass jar. I wasn't sure at first if that was the sound of 1st crack, so I did another 50g of Yirgacheffe roasting immediately and the same thing happened, so I am pretty sure that was the sound of first crack. The fan of the roaster does make a bit of noise, so at first I thought it would not be so easy to hear the sound of 1st crack, but I now know it is not the case.
Best wishes.

@Pavel Družba @Christo-Faulds Again, I have absolutely nothing against experimentation. I am definitely not looking for a definitive guide from Ikawa or anyone else. Coffee is a very complex subject, from growing the beans, treatment of the beans, roasting to grinding and brewing. There is no fixed rule for anything and so many variables. My point was absolutely NOT about getting detailed guidelines or instruction before experimentation. After all as I told you, I am already experimenting anyway. And it is not about wasting 50g of beans if some experiment goes wrong either. It is simply that, it would help us to understand how different parameters may affect the final roasting result if we have a basic guide. No one can tell you exactly how to alter a roasting profile to achieve a certain definitive result, but at least they can point you in the right direction. Of course you can always learn to do anything yourself without any help from anyone, just do a lot of experimentation and fail many times to learn. I have nothing against that at all. If you are a pioneer in something. Say you are the first surgeon in the world, you probably would have cut up many dead bodies to learn about anatomy and then probably perform surgery on 100 patients before you save the first one. But we are not in stone age anymore, and doctors are taught by experience teachers on surgery, so they don't need to blindly do experiment anymore. It does not mean they don't need to practice and learn the techniques themselves, or when they use their own brain and mind to alter or improve surgical techniques. Well, same with coffee roasting IMHO.

With roasting 50g at a time, one can really afford to mess about and refine their preferred roast level - don't be scared(!) it's exactly what the Ikawa is designed for. The beauty of all of this is a tweaked profile can then be replicated at the touch of a button. That is, until the greens are changed :p

@Roland - So I think the time when more detailed instructions are available will come, but maybe its good to use the time when they are not, to develop the intuitive feel for the system even faster by not being too constrained by the instructions and using a different part of the brain to build that "instictive" feel based on a feedback loop and minor changes to the curves :D Its the same way how instictive barebow archery works - when you not consciously analyze and aim, but through practice the brain uses the feedback loop and gets more and more precise in calculating the arrow trajectory ... sometimes I feel these subconscious ways are way more precise then what we can achieve through the conscious analytical part ...

@Roland - its true it would help to have some detailed guidelines, but at the same time - i think the one that we have allready - to pick one of the profiles and make small changes to see where it goes, is very good for getting the feel for it. We will make mistakes, but thats how we learn ;) I remember when I started using Portaspresso system, i communicated with Ross a lot. And he responded quickly and has been really nice and helpfull, yet he refused saying - doing this has this kind of effect, which I tried to make him say bunch of times, because what i knew from previous espresso system did not work too well ... he said I need to experiment to get the feel for it. And looking back, i agree with him now. Complete manual controll over everything in espresso is a very complex system to describe, yet I was able to learn so much in a month or two, and then i felt i need to change this or that to have effect in the direction I needed.

@Christo-Faulds ... yes its exactly like that - you add airflow and the "mixing" movement is bigger. It is very dependent on the weight of beans so it needs to be tweaked if heavy dense beans resist to move - but from observing the profiles provided I feel its not good to use too much air. So, knowing I can add more air, i am quite happy with that sort of unevenness I see in the roast as long as I like the taste in the cup. Usually the profile i use to start on different african or other dense bean is one of Ethiopias, which has quite low airflow, i will soon try to experiment with it too, but so far i leave it as it is as long as i dont see a bean stuck in the middle of the swirl for longer time. I can see the stay there for a few moments, but like a second or three. I can take some pictures of my testing set of Ethiopia today, and make some links to be able to post here ....

@Christo-Faulds Thank for seeing my Instagram profiles. From what I observed, the default roasting profiles for Burundi has no problem spinning the beans around in the roasting chamber, but as I mentioned earlier, roasting different "larger or heavier" beans with one of the profiles may need altering of the fan speed to swirl the beans around more efficiently.

@Pavel - One way to get a nice bright light into the roast chamber without worrying about the heat hurting a bulb would be to use fiber optics. That way the light sources is remote. Most fiber optic is made of strands of glass which should be able to tolerate the heat if placed carefully.

@All - one very special thing I have noticed from the first roast - the aroma that it produces is really pleasant and sweet. No smokiness. My wife likes it very much when I roast :) Great bonus "feature" :D

@IKAWA - :) and now, what I would love to see ... It would be great to be able to have direct controll over the roast, as someone else allready pointed out ... maybe just being able to manipulate the curve while roasting would be great. But I would say even more important for me seems to have the curve to be curve trully .. not just points with linear interpolation but bezier curve points as an option ....That would make me live happily with the number of points limitation, and most probably never needing even all of them (I think it would enhance the PRO version as well :D) - I have a background in CG and VFX, and seeing angular "curve" like this hurts me, as its both not nice and naturall ... the nature is about curves and flow, sharp angular changes like these are very rare. Today, after first roasts of most of Ikawa Select coffee on a default profile, and a succesfull brightening of the Yirgachefe roast (@Ikawa Thank you for the tips ... just moved the point you suggested a little less then advised and it made a big change that I like a lot) I did first two roasts of samples I had waiting a long time here. I had Papua here and Jamaica Blue Mountain, both just 50g, so I had one shot at them and had to make most of it. I started with Papua and used a prolonged Colombia profile, stopping it by judging the color and estimating a good point, but I did not like how went through - SO .. I have chosen E.Sidamo profile for Jamaica, just because it "looked right" (I have never roasted before, did not know JBM nor I roasted Sidamo before :D). I made it longer to be able to watch and stop the roast ... prayed to coffee gods and pushed the button. :D AND - one great thing is, I heard my first clear and obvious first crack with Jamaica, and then I knew it might work well. The second great thing is - I added smelling what goes out of the Ikawa to watching the colour of the beans ... and that kept me holding my urge to push the button and stop the roast just after the crack ... I held it there for bit over a minute after the FC, and I have to say after testing it on V60, for a blind shot roast its really great. I should have kept it there for a bit longer as its still a little bit underdeveloped, but ... it was my 11th roast in my life :) and second with no prepared profile. I think this illustrates how well Ikawa Home behaves, its readable, predictable, gives enough time at the end of the roast to find the balance .... I simply love it :D Thank you IKAWA.

@Ikawa coffee Ever consider to create a full manual mode to allow us to adjust the fan speed and the temperature in real time? I think this would be a great feature to let us try out some beans that have no recipe yet and create one. It should show at least a timer, sensor measurements, fan speed input, and target temperature input.

And one last thing - during my very first roast (Burundi) I have noticed something that might be maybe important - with the preset roast profile it seems the air flow has been a bit lower than it probably should be (the beans were moving - rotating together, but with very little to no "mixing" ) and also in the phase when they should be blown into the vessel no bean moved there. I then repeated the procedure as instructed by the manual - the blow has been a lot stronger and all went well. After that all roasts of Burundi had a stronger movement of the beans with "mixing" cleanly visible and faster rotation in the chamber, and even though they never go into the vessel during the regular blow out phase (probably because they are small, heavy and hard:)) but some of them do) all airflow seems constantly stronger. Do not know what it means, but I am happy that from the second roast on all looks repeatably the same.

@Christo, thanks for your input, that was very lucidly explained and is very good input. Much of what you describe is very understandable for a roaster like the Gene because of it's underlying technology and it's batch size. Although with time and experience I think you will be able to compensate for some of it's "characteristics" I think you will find the Ikawa a next generation roaster which overcomes most of those very issues. One exception would probably be the bean temperature vs exhaust temperature issue because the Ikawa home roaster also measures exhaust air (although it might be a bit closer to bean temp if, as I suspect, the probe in the Gene is further away in the exhaust path than in the Ikawa). All the rest should be covered: highly repeatable roast profile due to PID, less noisy, great cooling and chaff collection, ability to do lots of experimenting without wasting time or coffee (small batch size), clean, low smoke, good roast uniformity. Incidentally, for a project you might be able to PID your Gene with an external controller fairly inexpensively. I haven't specifically heard of anyone doing that but if you google you may find someone's done it and a description of what they used. If not, you could probably be the first to try possibly using something like Darrel has experimented with: Zallus Reflow Oven Controller https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1070729460/zallus-oven-controller. Let me know if you ever try!
It's a good opportunity to start learning with this compact roaster, which takes small batch (i.e. less waste) for experiment.

Sorry, just to clarify the last sentence of my last post re: starting a fire for people not familiar with coffee roasting - I wasn't talking of a safety issue or even something that would hurt the roaster. If you over-roast coffee it can catch fire inside the roaster but roasters are designed to handle this so it's not a big deal eve if it is something you want to avoid. You always need to watch the roaster carefully while roasting (especially in the dark range) because if you go too long and too dark you may start a fire in the roasting chamber - if that happnes you want to immediately terminate the roast and start the cooling cycle to put out the fire.

4) Colorimtetry: Not in the context of this project, but for a future version have you considered the potential for colorimetry (ie, a color sensor and light source) as a means truncate / terminate a given roast profile and start cooling? Although I understand that with your roaster once you dial in a roast it will be repeatable, terminating a roast by color rather than by time by measuring "average bean color" as they fly around might make your roaster more fool proof for consumers. Since your roaster is so fast I would guess that everything is time compressed which might make it easy to go too long on dark roasts where it can be tricky to get the timing right. Even in far slower roasters bean roast level changes fast in the dark range (often just a few extra seconds makes a big difference). For consumers it would be nice to have a more automated way to hit a desired roast level and avoid over roasting or even starting a fire.
Thanks

@Ikawa - Would you consider polling backers on color preferences for your color stretch goal? I'm not trying to detract from the red lovers but it's possible the majority might prefer another color (ie, black, charcoal, or silver). Market research is good!

3) Roast profile translation to drum roasters: I can see many consumers say this is the only roaster they will need due to ease of use and convenience particularly if they don't go through tons of coffee like coffee geeks often do. I can see coffee geeks like myself say they would use it that same way fairly often (as an on demand roaster to have a lot of day to day variety) but also say the other big attraction would be to be able to use your roaster to rapidly and inexpensively iterate on roast profiles (without going through a ton of coffee) prior roasting a larger amount on a prosumer (or small pro) drum roaster to get a larger batch size IF they can translate the roast profile easily from your roaster to achieve the same result in the cup. So my question is: will a roast profile that is optimized for a particular variety or blend on your roaster translate to a prosumer (or small pro) drum roaster and achieve the same (or very similar) result in the cup? Although I can understand how a temp profile should translate (as long as both machines are PID controlled) I don't understand how fan speed would translate. It would be pretty exciting if roast profiles did translate (read: if you helped make sure they translated) because I think it would help you sell a lot more roasters to coffee geeks. I think many coffee geeks who already own a drum roaster would be enticed to add your roaster to their collection in order to allow them to easily and rapidly dial in a roast before roasting a larger quantity on their drum roaster.
