campaign.story:
A non-locking blade is now available see latest update.
After a year of designing and prototype revisions, we've perfected the ultimate key holder and knife / tool in one- the Mini Q key organizer is finally here! This was a very detailed engineering process, all the way down to the tiniest of measurements to keep it not only compact but to make it the strongest that it can be. The goal was to create a compact rugged product with a refined touch.
Titanium brushed finish
Let me tell you how well built it is…the different Mini Q bodies are made of: 
• Aircraft grade Aluminum (strong light 50 grams or 1.7 oz.)
• High quality Brass (118 grams or 4.16 oz. recommended to use with 4 keys only)
• Grade 5 Titanium (78 grams or 2.7 oz. very strong and lightweight)
The finishes are smooth satin, brushed, and bead blasted that have turned out beautifully…
How Is it Built?
A one of a kind unique pivot post and lever has been designed to withstand  long time use. The clip is made small with a deep pocket loop to ride comfortably in your pocket. The posts are made from hard stainless steel to ensure no wear and tear on the threads and post. 
The Shape:
With just the right amount of radius added to the outer corners for comfort and feel, the lower notch is also the optimal size for placing your index finger for good grip while using the blades. The notches on the backside are shaped for popping out the keys with flick of your thumb.
Titanium brushed finish key holder knife
Everyday carry key organizer Titanium
The Blade:
The blades are 2.35 inches long and made from hardened 420HC stainless steel. It is design to be interchanged without removing the keys and vice versa. The lever is a standard folding knife mechanism with an upgraded pivot and the blades flip out easily and locks securely in place. The blades are sharp and ready for use. (A non-locking version will be made available if we hit our stretch goal).
Titanium brushed finish EDC key holder knife
Each Mini Q key organizer comes with one blade of your choice.
• Drop point blade 
• Bottle opener knife blade 
• Anteater utility blade ( 2 options - bottom sharp edge or bottom flat edge ) The Anteater Blade shown below has the bottom sharp edge. You can get this bottom section completely flat (no sharp edge) as an option.  
In addition you can purchase more blades, just add $14.00 to your pledge for each additional blade. You will have the opportunity to note which blade or blades you want in the ending survey.
Everyday carry knife blades
 Each stainless steel blade has a satin finish. 
 The Mini Q key organizer can also be used entirely without the blades.
Mini Q Dimensions Titanium
.5 inches with 4 keys
Quality:
The Mini Q is designed with custom manufacturing without cutting any corners.
• Hardened stainless steel and grade 5 titanium.
• Aluminum models are machined out of aircraft grade aluminum which is lightweight, yet strong. 
• The quality is first rate with every detail meticulously machined. 
• Stainless steel machine posts and screws allow a lifetime of use. 
• Allen heads used simply to look better and add more torque and won’t strip. Each screw head will have a rubber washer and nylon thread coating to prevent loosening.
• Stainless steel lever mechanism is designed to withstand normal wear and tear. 
• Mini Q is made for daily use. Easy to change out any keys and blades can be changed as well.
• It will hold keys with a hole diameter greater than 4.3 mm and length up to 63 mm.
PLAY

Example of a 3 key set up with no clip. 
PLAY

 Example of a 8 key set up with clip.
Durability: 
 • Extremely durable with a rust proof blade that is highly resistant to dulling and can hold an edge. 
 • Built to last - It has been tested, dropped, kicked and smashed - you can be 100% confident that your Mini Q can take a few punches.
EDC pocket knife key holder Titanium
 Comfort: 
 • Small, compact and ultra-light. 
 • You won’t notice the Mini Q riding in your pocket, rack sack or bag. 
 • Rounded corners to ensure comfort and no wear on pockets. 
 • If you choose to use the clip -  it's small with a deep pocket design to ride securely in your pocket without being distracting. 
Consolidate your everyday carry
Pocket clip
Practicality: 
• Stops the jingle of keys; consolidates into one compact unit.
• Slim locking blade. 
• Easy interchangeable keys or blades. 
• Clip or no clip, or tether it from the smart loop.
• Replaces your keychain with a productive tool. 
• Use it to open boxes or anything that requires more effort than your fingers. Cut, pry, pop and tighten…lots of uses. 
• Ideally holds up to 4 keys and up to 8 with extension posts. 
• No more lugging a heavy pocket knife or any other cumbersome tool. 
• Flip out the tool or blade for instant access in time of need. They are handy and may get more use than some of your keys. You will soon discover that it’s now an essential part of your everyday carry.
 What does it include?
Comes with loop to attach to bigger Keys.
Available finishes:
 Here are some examples of finishes:
Brass brushed finish -
 White powder coated aluminum -
White powder coated aluminum
Titanium brushed finish -
Titanium bead blasted finish -
Example: Titanium bead blasted finish (matte grey)
 Black Aluminum
Black hard anodized aluminum
Featured on:
To name a few
Add a little color contrast to your Mini Q! 
This stretch goal has been reached!
All backers now have the option of customizing your Mini Q with complimentary colored Hardware - Hardware includes :
- Knife blade thumbstud
- Key loop
- All screws
- Pocket clip
*Please choose only one color for all 4 of the above.
A non-locking blade is now available see latest update.
For Australia, UK, and the rest of Europe – this stretch goal was created just for you and anyone else who wants a non-locking blade.
A few things you must know before you opt for the non-locking blade. I will not have the new prototype for the non-locking blade completed before this campaign ends for you to see. 
If you choose the non-locking version in the ending survey, you need to be aware of the following: 
• It will not be available for delivery until September.
• It will only be available in titanium (brushed or bead blasted).
• The body will look identical to the locking version of the Mini Q – it will have a strong slipjoint mechanism instead.
*For those that want the locking version - the delivery date will still be August 2015.
My Mini Q Goals:
I set out to design the best key organizer and pocket tool knife while consolidating my everyday carry with a great looking product. Everyone carries keys and everyone needs a knife or tool at one point. If you’re like me - you carry a tool, a pocketknife, and keys - the Mini Q has not only made your life easier but is a good looking piece as your everyday carry.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The funds raised from Kickstarter will allow me to create the Mini Q on a larger scale and offer it to the public at an affordable price. But I need your help to do it!

Everything needed to kick off the manufacturing process is complete. The design and prototyping is done and all materials are in place. It’s just a matter of giving the factory the green light once the project is complete and funded.

I have worked with my machinist and manufacturer for some time now and have built a strong working relationship. My manufacturer is ready to go and delivery date is set. I am working with a factory that specializes solely with this type of product and materials, so I do not expect any hiccups, but just in case, I have padded the delivery date by one month. Most likely they will arrive on your door step sooner than you hope. 

I am excited to get the Mini Q in your hand so you can feel and experience the quality for yourself and streamline your everyday carry. 

Thank you for your support, 
Bryce

The Mini Q is Trademarked with Patent Pending. Quiet Carry is Trademarked.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hello Everyone,
So after what seems like a lifetime of waiting, the remainder of the Mini Q's are here - the non-locking Titanium versions and the remainder of your aluminum units are now assembled, boxed and ready to go!
A look into some of the manufacturing issues I've come across the last few weeks: The aluminum white powder coating has surprisingly been difficult to get right - we've had to throw away about 50 of them as they didn't coat properly but the ones that finally passed the quality test are looking good.

Hey guys! Excellent work on this. I do have a suggestion for if you ever iterate your product; Put the clip on the other side of the plate or make the plate reversible. With the clip on the side it is right now, the thumbscrew to open the blade is on the opposite side from where one's thumb naturally resides upon taking it out of a pocket. Instead of being able to immediately flick it open, it has to be rotated in the hand first. Different people seem to have different preferences in an EDC carry, and one of them is blade up or blade down in pocket. If your product is going to force one direction, I definitely recommend blade up instead of blade down.

campaign.story:
Probationary firefighters fighting their first fire
Why is this tool needed?
In the United States there are just over 1 million Firefighters putting their lives on the line every day for their neighbors.  These men and women go into battle better prepared than any generation before them, with equipment allowing them to go further into fires and survive impossible conditions.  However, the technological leaps in the fire industry used to fight fires have left behind the most basic operations of any fire attack: Accountability and Communication.  Outdated ID tag systems exist across the country today to account for firefighters' locations while on-scene.  70% of fire departments we've surveyed stated that the tag systems are unreliable and problematic.  PROBEE Safety was created to address the need to bring firefighter accountability into the age of big data and big solutions.  More importantly, our goal is to do this in a simple, accessible, and affordable manner that does not interfere with the working firefighter.
Additionally, once a firefighter enters a structure, the sole means of communication with operations outside is with a portable radio, and due to the cost of these, many firefighters have to do without. This means that incident command has a limited exterior perspective of the fire scene. This also forces command to rely heavily on their tag system and communication with a firefighter who is likely unaware of their actual position within a structure.
Our field-tested prototype assists First Responders with situational awareness, risk management, and most importantly, firefighter safety.  Our system blends rugged hardware with advanced software to deliver a functional product that we hope will become standard equipment for every firefighter.
How does our system work?
When a firefighter arrives on a fire scene, they go about their normal operations of fire suppression while being monitored by our POLO radio beacon. This device powers itself on and begins monitoring the firefighter for movement, their air supply, and live fire conditions around them. Upon recognizing a life-threatening situation, the POLO transmits an emergency broadcast out of the structure to one of four MARCO routers, which calculate the firefighter's location to within a quadrant and floor level.
This is how MARCOs are deployed around a building
I am sure you're wondering how these MARCO devices got into position, right? Well, this is the piece that requires a user interaction: placing one MARCO on each side of the structure based on the device’s alphabetic designation (A, B, C, or D), which corresponds to the fire industry’s best practices. The MARCOs can be placed at any time during the fire attack, to ensure that the fire operation is not interrupted.  In most cases, these can be placed during the initial walk around of the structure.
MARCO routers deployed on the A side of the fire structure
To close the loop from data to rescue, in the event of an alarm, a fire officer equipped with a tablet will be made aware of the developing situation by an alert on the PROBEE application. When not being used, the application runs passively in the background and maintains communication with the deployed MARCOs and POLOs, available for use as needed.  Let's face it, our fire officers have other things to worry about, but when they really need that crucial information, the PROBEE Safety system will be within reach to facilitate a rescue.
Current State of Product Development & Limitations
Our team designs and manufactures communication tools for use in rugged environments.  Our system is designed for wood and masonry residential structures, which account for a majority of the structures in the United States.  Between 2001 and 2010, 57% of firefighter deaths and 80% of firefighter injuries occurred in single or twin family structures.  We intentionally avoided the high-rise and commercial structure market because we felt that a simple, cost effective solution could be developed to address a significant portion of the market, as 80% of structural fires in the US are in residential structures.  Our research indicates that the PROBEE Safety system provides the most accurate elevation information in the industry.
PROBEE has been deployed in three live burn tests at a local fire academy to verify functionality in an Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH) environment.  These tests have provided valuable information to our team at a prototype stage, namely system functionality at temperature, data transmission capability, elevation algorithm adequacy, and ease of use.  We’ve also deployed our system multiple times in non-burning structures to check our quadrant algorithms and horizontal location functionality, and have been pleased with the results.
PROBEEs innovative elevation detection technique
We’ve been able to achieve everything we’ve set out to do thus far using commercially available off-the-shelf components and injection molded/3D printed cases, greatly reducing development costs and issues.  We’ve reached a point where further development will require formal testing to show that our system meets the relevant NFPA consensus standards, an important seal of approval needed for acceptance in the industry.
How will we use the Kickstarter funds?
We need your help to get us through the testing recommended for all equipment worn by emergency responders today.  This includes burning, drowning, dropping, dusting, and exploding our poor system to find its weak spots.  We also need to take our development-friendly software and package it into a nice tablet GUI before the product is ready to hit the fire station.
We are at a point where we will be procuring molds, downsizing the power supply, and conducting formal bench and field testing for our product certifications.  Our minimum quantity for production runs is about 20 units (one system), so we can focus on quality rather than worrying about funding for a large minimum order.
To get this fully deployed, our budgeted need is approximately $30,000, which will provide us with enough funding to go through the remaining development steps to get us to the first production run.
With your help we can provide firefighters with the information necessary to detect dangerous situations and facilitate proactive responses.
Our timeline for the coming months
REWARDS!!!
The Limited Edition PROBEE Safety Supporter T-shirt!
All womens' sizes available in Sunset Orange or Navy and Mens' in Kiwi Green or Navy
The PROBEE Safety Chamois Cloth, what more can be said?

YOUR help will make PROBEE possible!
 Any pledge amount brings us one step closer to our goal of improving fire scene communication and accountability. Show that you support giving firefighters the tools they want by clicking the "Back This Project" button at the top of the page, or by helping us spread the word by sharing our page.
We appreciate your support of our mission. THANK YOU for your help!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
One of the hardest parts of deploying equipment in the fire industry is offering a useful product at a great value. What has given us the upper hand is a deep understanding of firefighting techniques, and the engineering expertise to put a product together at an affordable price. PROBEE was born from the fire industry and has a strong base of enthusiastic supporters eagerly awaiting the word that our system is ready to be deployed in their station.

Our functioning Polo units need some minor refinement to facilitate mass production and interoperability with existing industry equipment.

Our team of engineers and firefighters, in coordination with our local ISO 9001:2008 contract manufacturer, have experience successfully delivering projects. Products regularly in use within the fire industry have successfully passed the same tests we are faced with. We're confident that the development, testing, and manufacturing challenges that we will likely face can be overcome by pulling from our collective experiences and applying a bit of ingenuity to solve the issues as they arise.

No one wants to see a great product executed poorly. We have worked extremely hard to ready the PROBEE Safety system for Kickstarter, product testing, and fulfillment, but here are what we see as the risks:

MANUFACTURING: Creating the tooling to manufacture a product of this level of intricate detail is expensive and requires expert knowledge to get it right. There is typically a 6-week lead time to create the tooling for a product of this complexity and this is where delays could occur. To minimize that possibility, we're working with tooling manufacturing partners with a track record for prompt quality.

PRODUCT ADJUSTMENTS: As the PROBEE Safety system gets geared up for production, there will likely be some minor adjustments to improve the final product. Pre-production prototypes are made to test and refine the product and allow us to incorporate our adjustments and those suggested by experienced manufacturing partners, along with making any changes required for compliance certifications (such as UL 913 requirements). Changes will always be made for the benefit of our firefighters, and we will let you know exactly how and why any are made.

FULFILLMENT: Sometimes things go awry that simply can't be planned for: a supplier misses a deadline, a machine breaks down, or a shipment gets lost. Those things could cause a delay. To minimize the possibility of delays, we've built our manufacturing team and coordinated our production and fulfillment schedules.

THE FINE PRINT (PLEASE READ THIS!)

-- Our system is a tool and not a life saving device. The system provides information and what users do with that information is up to them. Common sense, experience, and good judgment should be used when relying on the information provided by our system during the decision making process. Tools don't save people; firefighters do.

-- Our system is designed to supplement, not replace, existing PPE, PASS devices, radios, and tools currently used in the fire industry during a response.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
We want to THANK Richard and Lauren Hearn for their generous pledge of $7,000 to go to Haiti and deliver a box of SolarPuffs to the girls at the orphanage!!!! 
Lauren is Richard's 14 year old daughter who selected this pledge!!!Lauren!!!We are INSPIRED by YOU!!!
THANK YOU!!!! Richard and Lauren you are HUGE HEROS to us!!!!
        A little lantern with a HUGE impact.
Video by Fredric King of Fountainhead Transmedia, Fountainhead.com
The SolarPuff is the ideal product. It's a patent pending solar lantern that packs flat and easily pops open into a charming cube of light. Beautifully designed with Origami technology to appeal to everyone from the most discerning design conscious hipster to a hermit living in the hills.It's perfect for emergencies, camping, hiking, boating, around the pool, in the pool, as a night light, in your car... You get the picture, its uses are endless, and it makes for a fabulous house gift.  
Simply Put
Designed with sustainable and high-performance fabric specifically engineered for durability, flexibility and water resistance, and structured for adaptability and recyclability.
It's light weight, just 2.5 ounces.
It floats and can withstand complete immersion under water.
For as many hours as you charge it in the sun, it will provide light for just as long. For example, 5 hours of charging in the sun will provide illumination to light up a 10 X 10 room for 5-8  hours. Charge it for 8 hours and it will light for 8-12 hours.
It has a shelf life of over three years.
How It Works
SOLARPUFF how to Open and Close
PLAY

Add-On: Option
To add on to your pledge go to the top right of the page and under the green button, "You're a Backer", click the blue button "Manage" 
-If you add $25 to your pledge you can donate 1 SolarPuff to Nepal. 
-If you add $50 to your pledge, you can donate 2 SolarPuffs to Nepal.
We will send a survey at the end of the campaign, asking you to clarify what you want for your pledge. Just make sure what you want adds up properly, corresponding to the rewards listed.
  It's Different
Our  lantern distinguishes itself from other solar lanterns because of its modern flatpack pop-open design. The purpose of the SolarPuff's design component is fostering our belief in good design for all, in both the first world and third world countries. 
The SolarPuff looks stunning traversing poolside to camp side to Subsaharan huts. Our product is engineered to flatten and then pop open into a clean, beautiful, modern cube lamp which is a critical distinction for transforming poverty into dignity. 
This little light flat packs to 0.25 inches and can fit in any back pocket. It boasts 100 lumens and can fully charge in the sun in 8 hours lasting for 8-12 hours of light. If you only get to charge it for 5 hours, it’s ok, it will still last for 5-8 hours of light. 
The circuit contains a photovoltaic solar panel, 10 bright white LEDS and a lithium-ion polymer battery. Although the circuit is made in China, the special fabric of the expandable bladder which is the light disfusing element, is made in Connecticut. 
It is specifically engineered to withstand extreme outdoor environments. This product is revolutionizing the way we light our world. It is a formidable champion of beautiful, mobile, modern, and sustainable lighting, simply using the limitless renewable awesomeness of our sun.
AWARDS + PRESS
A Little History
Background
This light was first developed by Alice Min Soo Chun for emergency relief after the Haiti earthquake. In 2010, while teaching at Columbia University, Alice returned from Haiti and converted her architecture lab into an innovation center for disaster relief. Alice shared her years of research on integrating thin film substrates with photo voltaics and the idea of an inflatable solar light with the goal of creating sustainable solutions for disaster relief. The first prototype for the SolarPuff, along with all other inflatable solar lanterns currently on the market, were born in her lab.  Alice holds four patents for the inflatable solar lantern and solar light assembly.
Where we are Today 
It took quite a few prototypes to find the right fabric, best components and the unparalleled design.  We wanted to make sure the fabric was non-toxic (PVC free) to the environment and full recyclable. We finally produced the perfect combination this past summer (2014). 
In September 2014, we signed a licensing agreement with a distributor in Japan who received their first order for SolarPuffs in December 2014. All have sold and they are awaiting their next shipment.
In March 2015, we signed a distribution agreement with a Caribbean distributor and we are currently speaking with other distributors in India, Belgium, UK, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Nairobi, Singapore and Hong Kong for starters.
Who "WANTS" A SolarPuff?
This superior solar inflatable light is great for the home, gardens, pools, boating enthusiasts, camping, hiking, corporate premiums and military applications. It is also the most ideal lantern for emergency and disaster relief, due to its light weight and it's the most hygienic since there is no need to use your mouth to inflate.The light weight design makes for lower shipping costs and its foldability allows for dense packing of 80+ units per box. The high tech fabric creates a delightful dispersion of light. Every household on the earth would benefit from owning a SolarPuff. It's the perfect gift for everyone.
Who "NEEDS" A SolarPuff?
The IFC (International Finance Corporation) estimates that globally, over 1.6 billion people – possibly as high as 3 billion – are living without access to reliable electricity. 
 According to figures from the International Energy Agency, at least 20% of the planet's inhabitants are still without the simple luxury of a light switch.
So how do they light their homes and cook their food? They are using kerosene, wood, crop waste, charcoal, coal and dung. Worldwide, over 500 million households use kerosene, for lighting.
According to studies conducted by Dr. Evan Mills, founder of the Lumina Project, an initiative that promotes low-carbon alternatives to fuel-based lighting, "kerosene (or as he refers to it, "dirty lighting") consumes 77 billion liters of fuel worldwide, costing its predominantly impoverished end-users a total of $36 billion annually."Kerosene costs 25 to 30 percent of a family’s income — globally. The poor do not use kerosene because it is cheap — they are kept poor in significant part because they must rely on expensive, dirty kerosene. .
What We Want to Do  
With your help, we can revolutionize how people are lighting their homes. We want people to be prepared with a SolarPuff in their home for when the next Hurricane Katrina or Sandy hits and we want to provide clean sustainable lighting to those that need it most. 
Calculated from research, if everyone in the United States used a SolarPuff for one hour a day instead of a regular light bulb, it would save over 11 BILLION tons of CO2 emissions from going into the air each year!! 
In the United States 75% of the air pollution in urban areas is due to energy consumption from buildings. Solight Design wants to design and manufacture beautifully architected solar solutions that people will want in their homes and, at the same time, help eradicate pollution, poverty and excessive energy consumption!  
We don't want to stop there! We want to change the reliance on dirty fuels to light the homes of people living off the grid. Globally there are at least 1.6 billion people without reliable access to electricity. This lack of access to efficient energy becomes even more apparent in rural areas of developing countries where most lighting is fueled by kerosene, which is not only toxic but extremely expensive, creating a vicious cycle of poverty.
The HELIX vs PUFF:
Many of our supporters have been asking how the Helix and Puff are different. Well the Helix is a Twist and a little more compact than the SolarPuff. It is made from recyclable TPU, a thermoplastic that has a unique memory for shape retention. you can see in the video here that a slight push will start the deflation process in motion and it will remember to flat pack back to a square. Also the light is more uniform than the SolarPuff since the SolarPuff has more a a spectrum of light. The SolarPuff has a ziplock pouch for packaging and the Helix has a paper packaging. The SolarPuff  light diffuser is made from a Sail Cloth Fabric that is made in the USA and the Helix light diffuser material (TPU)is made in China. Hope this helps!
PLAY

Helix
Helix
SolarPuff packs into a Polygon
SolarPuff
Who Are We?
Alice Min Soo Chun and Stacy Kelly, Co-Founders
Alice Min Soo Chun is a Co-Founder and CEO of Solight Design and the inventor of the Solar Inflatable Light: SolarPuff. She is  Professor of Design and Material Culture at Parsons the New School and was the Director of the Materials Resource Lab. She was Adjunct Assistant Professor of Architecture at Columbia University and at the University of Pennsylvania. After many years of research in integrating solar photo voltaics with thin film substrates, she developed the first prototype for the solar inflatable light in 2009. When the Haiti earthquake happened, she turned her studio at Columbia University into an innovation studio for developing solutions to help Haiti, and then the application of the solar inflatable light became the Solarpuff. She has built award-winning community outreach projects; her work has been published in the New York Times, Architectural Record, Dwell, and The Journal of Architectural Education. Her book entitled GROUND RULES in Humanitarian Design, published with Wiley Press in 2015, is about design principles for the long-term sustainability.
Stacy Kelly is a Co-Founder and Chief Operating Officer of Solight Design. Stacy has the dual role of being responsible for managing the manufacturing and shipment of our products while also developing strategic business relationships. Solight Design is Stacy’s third entrepreneurial venture. She sold her first to American Health Magazine. In 2007, Stacy founded her second venture, Mobile Previews, a mash-up of mobile video streaming, SMS alerts, sharing and polling in one mobile application. In between start-ups Stacy worked as a publisher for some of the largest media companies in the world such as ABC, Disney, Reed Elsevier, Entrepreneur Media and Advanstar across a variety of markets and digital platforms, including. entertainment, toys and licensing. It was as publisher of Entrepreneur’s Business Start-Up that she realized that her real passion is in helping new businesses find their markets and build out their sales and business development strategies. Stacy received her MBA from San Francisco State University and her undergraduate degree from the University of Connecticut.
Alison Thompson is the First official Ambassador to the Haiti Ministry of Environment.  On September 11, 2001 Alison was a first responder at Ground Zero and volunteered there for nine months. In 2004, Alison flew to Sri Lanka after the Asian tsunami and remained for two years operating a field hospital and rebuilding a village. There she was named the Angel of Galle by the Sri Lankan people where she founded the first Community Tsunami Early-warning/Disaster Center in Sri Lanka. Alison helped manage a 65,000 person IDP camp and field hospital. Alison then Co-founded WeAdvance, an organization combating gender-based violence throughout Haiti. Alison created The Third Wave volunteer Disaster aid command center in The Rockaways, NY after the Hurricane Sandy disaster in New York, and another Third Wave chapter in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan. Her Random House book "The Third Wave" is about inspiring others to volunteer. In 2010, Alison was awarded the 'Order of Australia' by Australian Government and Queen Elizabeth II for her contribution to mankind. She was also awarded the 'Medal of Excellence' by US Army General Simeon Trombitas. Alison lectures on volunteering, women's rights and CSR via the American Program Bureau to colleges and corporations worldwide.
Why Kickstarter?
We need capital and your support to:
Scale inventory 
Lower COG
Build Infrastructure 
Build-out worldwide distribution
Marketing, advertising and PR
Bring the Helix from prototype to reality
Product development & research 
REWARDS
Just added to aid Nepal
Pledge $25 or more  
NEW NEPAL EARTHQUAKE RELIEF: GIVE ONE. To aid the Nepal people we've added a new reward. Give one (1) SolarPuff to Nepal Disaster Relief. Thank you. Estimated delivery: May 2015  
Pledge $50 or more  
NEW NEPAL EARTHQUAKE RELIEF: GET ONE, GIVE ONE. To aid the Nepal people we've added a new reward. Give one (1) to Nepal Disaster Relief and get one (1) for yourself. Do good, feel good. Thank you for your support. Estimated delivery: May 2015 Only ships to: Canada, United States, European Union  
Pledge $1,900 or more  Limited reward (2 left of 2) NEW NEPAL EARTHQUAKE RELIEF: GIVE ONE FULL BOX: To aid the Nepal people we've added a new reward. Give an entire box of SolarPuffs to Nepal Disaster Relief. You'll be sending useful aid to those that need it most right now. Estimated delivery: May 2015
(l to r) Origami star, SolarPuff, SolarHelix Prototype, Haiti
What's the difference between the SolarPuff and the SolarHelix?
The major difference between the two products is that the Helix is made of recyclable TPU which is a translucent ThermoPlastic and the SolarPuff is made of recyclable PET(Polyethylene terephthalate).
The other differences include: 
Light dispersion - The Helix disperses the light uniformly. Whereas the SolarPuff, has a spectrum of light dispersion and is prism-like as the light transfers through the high tech fabric material. 
Folding technology - Both use origami principles yet the Helix is a twist fold and pack motion. The SolarPuff has a pinch and fold motion. 
Costs  - TPU is less expensive and allows us to produce a economical version of the SolarPuff.
In all other components and functions, they are the same. They both float as the solar circuit is completely protected in a vacuumed sealed bladder. They both recycle. They charge the same and have the same lumenosity. They have equal lighting and will last just as long. And, finally, both have three settings, low, high and flash.
Check out the video at the top of the page to see how we demo the SoalrPuff vs the Helix,

I'd like to add in again as well, the SolarPuff in MoMa's catalogue is not new and was brought up earlier in comments when a disgrunted backer flagged the creators online listing on MoMa. As I mentioned in that instance, SolarPuff is not a new product and as described, the campaign is for upgrading materials in SolarPuff for mass production. The original SolarPuff has been selling through MoMa since 2011. This is not the same product that is in the hands of backers that have and will be receiving them.

Sarah Walker's response is certainly articulate and thoughtful. On the subject of MoMa I can only speculate that if one were trying to launch a product, receiving an offer to having it sold - a marketing coup - would be irresistible. I can certainly understand why someone might feel some rancoeur upon seeing a creation at the MoMa store while pledgers are still waiting. If someone is able to raise capital through Kickstarter, and part of their project is to launch a successful business that doesn't make pledgers customers or shareholders. I certainly didn't intend to suggest that having a successful creation on kickstarter bestows some sort of transcendant virtue that renders all criticism petty. But the process of realizing goals belongs to the creator, and I find too much focus on criticizing timelines, missed targets, etc.Drains attention away from the opportunity projects represent.

I know people are nagging you about their puff not arriving. I just want a rough estimate when I should receive it in Australia? If you say end of September or even October that is fine, I just want to know the time when I should be concerned that something had gone wrong. No stress, I have electricity down here in Kangeroo country.
But, this has been a nice project for me, others maybe not so nice.

Humanitarian efforts and interesting product development were, indeed, the reasons I joined this campaign. Now I wonder if I primarily subsidized a later-stage marketing-outreach campaign. That's my concern. It's all essentially water under the bridge at this point. Glad to have an estimated ship date. Good luck with the remainder of this endeavor.

I understand peoples' frustration when they are expecting something and it doesn't arrive when they were hoping. But I think some have lost sight of the point of this project and its vision. The creators are not titans of manufacturing. They are not Apple or General Electric. They have no doubt experienced the usual challenges in managing factory orders, with everything ranging from quality control to environmental and labour standards. I didn't support this solely to "get my lanterns", but because I found it was a compelling and worthwhile project that deserved support from as many people as possible. Of course I'm looking forward to receiving one and using it the next time I go "off grid", and to giving one to my family to be amazed with, but honestly, aside from those who are really going far away to deliver pledges as part of humanitarian missions, we should chill and be grateful our support has born fruit - even if it turns out to be late fall or winter.

Your product is good - your defense of your approach is reprehensible - if you want to make money - then own it. There is no shame in making money only in cloaking it in charity.

I don't believe anyone would question the merits of charity. But as you said it is voluntary, never forced. A simple poll in the survey would have settled the issue. I am sure as well tons of backers would be happy to wait. Those of us with a single annual camping trip who confirmed delivery beforehand may have chosen not to. Promising one thing and doing another is unethical and a generally a poor business practice, even when for a good cause. (and against the principles of kickstarter)

I guess that I am going to be one of the 'Scrooges', because I am disappointed about this also. I specifically bought these for a camping trip in July (and I barely have time to go camping even once a year), and now I'm not sure if I'll get any use out of them. And they would have been SO PERFECT for the trip, too. Charity should be voluntary, you shouldn't be forced to do it. You told us about the 4000 you already had in stock and you promised it to us as soon as the project ended. The way I see it, as soon as the project ended, we Kickstarter backers owned those units you had in stock, you were just holding them for us until you could ship them. Now, you have decided to donate OUR units, and COMPLETELY go back on your delivery promises without even asking us how we felt about it. So, we are being forced to donate our units to charities (in exchange for later deliveries) instead of giving us the option to do it willingly (and from the comments, A LOT of people would have done it willingly). The LEAST you could have done is have a poll to see if your backers would agree to do this before you just decided to do it on your own. I'm sure it's true that the people in Nepal need it now more than any of us, but that will still be true months from now when the next shipments come in. So if we are going to make sure that the needy get it first before the backers, we will NEVER get our pledges because there will ALWAYS be someone more needy (Nepal, the orphanage, the next natural disaster, etc.). I know that this will probably be one of the more unpopular comments, but before you flame me for being greedy and uncaring, just know that I added an extra $50 to my pledge just so that I could send 2 more units to Nepal than I was already sending because I actually do care. I just don't think it was right for the creators to make this decision without our input first.

Alice Min Soo Chun is colleague and dear friend of fifteen years. She is ingenious, generous and humble as a practitioner and as an educator. Unfortunately, in our culture, kindness and humility may be mistaken for weakness and preyed upon. I also know Andrea Sureshta and Anna Stork as they were students in a first year design studio that I taught at the Graduate School of Architecture at Columbia, and, I sat on the review of the Haiti studio when they presented large scale umbrella lights before Alice shifted the scale of the studio projects to smaller realizable designs. I am very disappointed in the way success has been sought at the expense of others and at the vindictiveness of Anna's campaign against Alice Chun. Andrea and Anna fit the model of the start-up and the focus on youth and ingenuity in design fields and the culture at large. Alice has been reluctant to tell her story as a single mother, as inventor, as designer at multiple scales, as an educator... Unfortunately, in the United States, the general populace seems to believe the "those who can't teach" ethos. As someone with a successful practice sustained simultaneously while a dedicated educator, I write to refute this. Architecture design problems require craft and uniquely reflect their creators. A well-crafted problem or program contains inherent possible solutions. Without the well-crafted problem and the nurturing of the instructor the design project as such would not be conceived. For a student to claim sole authorship of a design work in the contemporary design studio is not accurate in most cases. Further, instructors run the risk of having their ideas co-opted without credit should they share their work too freely. The situation in design studios is more complex and cooperative than is admitted. I am so happy to see Alice clarified the facts regarding her relationship as a patent holder of LuminAid and posted the patents. As a self-inflating structure, "SolarPuff & SolarHelix are a unique little lights" that were designed with a mission to help those in need and they are also beautiful well made objects. Based on how well this Kickstarter campaign has done despite slander, it seems the market and populace believe in the ability of these little lights to Power On.

Alice Min Soo Chun was one of my first professors in architecture nearly 20 years ago and she has been steadfast in her support of my career. I could not name of a more generous and talented design instructor and the product reflects those characteristics. I am so proud to support this project.
Keep up the good work and Good Works! We are both eager to get these and put them to use. Thanks a bunch.

Its rare to see an innovative idea being use to make the world a better place for all its inhabitants, while still respecting the planet we live on. I believe if your cause, and wish you nothing but success on your endeavors.

Due to the controversy I had reduced my pledge to $25, but thanks to your documented review I have increased my pledge to $75 to help those in Nepal! I realize that the changes will probably result in not using the product for summer camping. But, your integrity and world wide needs deserve priority!!
Thank you for this comprehensive response to the issues raised!

Only Alice, Andrea and Anna know the truth. There are official documents that name Alice as a co-inventor on the solar inflatable light. Now it appears that Anna & Andrea's packlite 12 is infringing on Alice's SolarPuff patent. http://www.google.com/patents/US20120224359 In addition, take a look at the link to FAARM. http://faarm.org/projects/solar-puff-inflatable-solar-lamp. This link has been up for almost 5 years. Here you see the prototypes for the SolarPuff. It seems to me that Andrea and Anna have been riding Alice’s coat tails all along.

However, I simply love solar puff and wanted to back this project just to help people in Nepal who lost their home, life and history. I have a friend who was just there for her wedding on the day of the earthquake. She is staying in Nepal after the event, struggling and trying to support her family and their friends but the process of receiving aids is complicated. As a friend, I would like to help her and her new family, and I believe sending SolarPuff would somehow cheer them up. The design inspired by origami would also soothe her homesickness since she is from Japan. I simply love the product and just want them to be distributed to physically and mentally support the people in the disaster.

Oh, and thank you for giving credits to the inspirations and people behind this project - Alice! Your story and your motivation behind creating SolarPuff is inspiring -- don't we all need to do our part to make this earth and the air we breathe livable for our children and their children...
Can't wait to see more beautiful products from SolarPuff!

I was an intern of Alice's in 2009 whilst I was a student at Parsons, I also had her as a professor in the graduate program. Alice is one of the most brilliant, generous and giving professors I have ever had. As an intern, I helped Alice research and make prototypes using LEDs, and small solar panels, She taught me how to make simple circuits to connect the LEDs to a lithium battery and solar panels. During this time we made variations of small scaled origami forms made from high tech fabric to thin clear plastic sheets. One of the prototypes was an inflatable, others were origami shapes.This is a life changing product that is so beautifully designed. It resonates the ideals and values that she has instilled in many, including myself.
The backstory as played out in the comments made interesting reading. Is Alice is on the patent for luminaid as well since it was through the university?

As a student who participated in the course mentioned in the comments below, I feel the need to state what I remember. I have no recollection of an inflatable light as a research option presented at the onset of our class. I do remember the development and presentation of the idea by Anna and Andrea. It goes without saying that all of our projects were developed in collaboration with each other. This dynamic is at the heart of how we learned in school, and how we continue to work as professionals. The legitimacy of a professors role as a participant in the development of their students ideas is clear and unquestionable. The pursuance of those ideas apart from the students who developed them is not. I wish the best for everyone and hope that your hard work continues to benefit you and those whom you serve.
Thanks.
If you need to prioritize, I suggest you ship first the pledges (or portion of pledges) with destination humanitarian reliefs. I can surely wait June or July to get my portion.

@Creator Would you please elaborate more on what you mean about "It will have a shelf life of over 3 years"? Does the material get more brittle and become prone to cracking from long term folding/unfolding and UV exposure?

I was one of Alice's students that went to Haiti as a student at Parsons, have the utmost respect for her, her values, and what she is doing here. I have no doubt that this was one of Alice's many ideas. Marlisa Wise was there, she wrote the comment trying to discredit Alice. Marlisa was so disrespectful to Alice and the other students on that trip, she was supposed to be helping, but her demeanor was unprofessional and attitude was in appropriate, and down right mean. At the end of the trip we were all asked to survey the trip and Marlisa was the only thing we all would have liked to have changed, but, I guess some people never change...

Like others in the comments below, I have given $1 only in order to help shed some light (pun intended) on the backstory of this project. I was once a student of Alice's, (and later a collaborator and co-teacher) and I was a student in the studio Alice taught in which she claims to have asked students to work with inflatable lights - this never happened. Anna and Andrea began to develop the LuminAid from their own independent research, LuminAid was completely their design and Alice started presenting the idea of the SolarPuff as her own only after Anna and Andrea made it clear that they would continue to develop LuminAid beyond their initial work in the studio. Its unfortunate to see that this misrepresentation has continued and the SolarPuff is being passed off as something it is not - there is certainly room in the world for many great designers to be working on behalf of the public good - but this seems like a good old fashioned case of intellectual theft and crafty marketing. It should be fine for a teacher to admit being inspired by their students without having to rewrite history to claim influence for the work of others.

I backed this project because I liked the idea and because I could not submit this post unless I was a backer. consumers know that companies produce products to make a profit. PLEASE do not be so sanctimonious. If you were doing this to help the poor you wouldn't be emphasizing it in your ads. We're not all Obama voters.

Hi David Li - I bought the solar puff from the website www.solight-design.com. I also donated here so that I could help with the people in Nepal.

I'm just chiming in after seeing all these posts, I hate to be a downer, for mitch and smrakocy, but its clear from all the earlier comments by the creator, that she didn't take her students ideas, she shared and in fact she spurred them on to dedicating their lives to it and she has every right to pursue her ideas, and she did too! Who are we to say it wasn't? wish I had someone like her in school. It seems that in general the educational system here is rewarding too many kids for being mediocre. Students here get to grad schools with huge egos and false sense of entitlement.

It is a great, effective and genuine product that has years of research, time and effort embedded in it. I congratulate both the SolarPuff and LuminAID and all other similar products that exist in their efforts to create change, raise awareness and enlighten the world.

Dear SolarPuff Makers - I received my SolarPuff yesterday and it's great! I'm surprised at how bright it is. The point is, yes borrowing happens, but the shoulders Einstein is referring to aren’t his own student’s they are Isaac Newton’s. An educator fosters an environment for ideas to thrive, they don’t harvest them.
Mike Robitz

At LuminAID, we stand behind the originality of our products and our intellectual property rights. We firmly believe in integrity, hard work, and providing the best possible service and products to our customers. I wanted to share our story to encourage all student inventors to stand by their innovations and keep their ultimate goals in mind despite the difficult challenges they may face. If anyone has any further questions, please feel free to email me at anna@luminaid.com. Thank you for all the questions about LuminAID.

I left my unsolicited review (below) because my experience with Solarpuff is flawless, and so different from the badmouthing of "Kenny". I am a real person, I am not affiliated with the Solarpuff project sponsors.

I bought a Solarpuff via the website. Mine is fantastic! Fulfillment was blazingly quick. The Solarpuff charged nicely even through my window (my apt has no balcony, so I wondered if it could get charged through the tinted glass on my building - it can). The amount of light seems similar to what I get from my high-end Koncept LED lamp; the Koncept lamp is rated for 14,000 hours of use and costs around $150-300 plus shipping. The Solarpuff is much cheaper, doesn't use electricity, and has a cool design (though in a different way from the Koncept); I understand Solarpuff has only a one-year warranty. Bottom line: I'm a super-picky shopper, and I think Solarpuff is a terrific value. I'm busy recommending Solarpuff to friends.

campaign.story:
Three ceramic pots, a glass reservoir, and a steel base make Tableau, the latest piece by the award winning Dutch designers at Pikaplant. 
                               We want to make plantkeeping so easy that anyone can do it. We believe greener living is better living, and we think everyone should be growing herbs, crops, and beautiful plants everywhere. That's why we started Pikaplant, and that's why we created Tableau.
Are you away from home a lot for work and travels? Are you forgetful when it comes to watering your plants? Do you know anyone who is? Tableau is an automatic house plant watering tray. It waters your plants so you don't have to.
It's hard to keep house plants healthy and happy. Over-watering and under-watering are two of the biggest problems faced by aspiring home gardeners. That's because most plants like to be watered in a steady rhythm. 
When we designed Tableau's irrigation system, we looked to an obvious source for inspiration, nature. In nature a plant gets its water in a wet-dry cycle. The wet allows roots to absorb water. The dry lets them air out and breathe. This is good for a plant's roots, making it grow strong and healthy. 
Tableau mimics this natural cycle to automatically water your plants. Tableau makes growing leafy greens, bright florals, and tasty herbs super easy. Grow plants for food. Grow plants that clean the air. Grow plants for fun. They'll brighten up any room.
Designed in the Netherlands, its simple minimalist aesthetic brings out the best in your plants. We've used basic materials like glass, steel, and ceramics because we believe in making quality products. Tableau's sleek design brings a simple tranquility into your home or work space.      
Watering your plants with Tableau is easy. Just make sure there's water in the reservoir and Tableau does the rest. The reservoir is easy to lift off of the base for refilling, so you can place your plants away from a water source. By watering your plants from below, your plants decide how much to drink. The reservoir contains enough to water three plants for around a month.  
Our unique ebb-and-flow technology mimics one of the key water cycles found in nature: ground water. Rather than slow-releasing water from the reservoir, Tableau provides water in a wet-dry cycle for strong roots and healthy plants. Once your plants have absorbed all of the water in the base, it stays dry for a few days before refilling with water.    
Staying true to nature, we've designed Tableau to work using zero electricity. The bi-valve system that controls the water flow from the reservoir to the base is sensitive to humidity and pressure. Zero electricity also means zero wires, meaning you can place your plants and Tableau wherever you want. 
Scientific studies have shown that a plant-rich environment boosts creativity and productivity. Plants reduce stress and clean the air. Use Tableau in your kitchen, living room, or work space. Grow crops, grow herbs, grow beautiful plants. It's easy. 
Joost is a lifelong inventor and tech head. He built a gaming console at age six using parts salvaged from a tape deck and a dot matrix printer. He makes Tableau work and he’s the caring owner of a multitude of healthy house plants.
Danny comes from a horticultural background. His great aunt and uncle have run an award winning orchid nursery in Java for over 60 years. After a recent visit he imported 100 orchid seedlings to the Netherlands, only to see them all die within a year.
Nynke is the ultimate multi-tasker. She represents the larger team dedicated to making Tableau a reality: the Pikapeeps. Every day she reaches out to others and shares our story because she knows this unique product needs to get made.
Make sure the reservoir contains water and Tableau will automatically water your plants. It’s easy to lift the reservoir off of the base, so you can fill it at any watering station. Then simply place it on the base to connect. Water will flow down into the base. The top of the base is covered in a capillary fabric that acts as a wick. The bottoms of the pots have holes through which the soil makes contact with the fabric, so your house plants can drink. After they’ve finished the water, the base stays dry for a few days before fresh water flows down from the reservoir and the cycle continues.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Product Development
The Tableau design is finished, but there are some technical details to tweak. We always do this in collaboration with production partners and suppliers. We've kept the design of Tableau as simple as possible, and we're speaking with multiple production partners. With a product of this complexity this phase shouldn't take more than a month. 

Production
We've spoken to our production partners and production between August and November is both feasible and realistic. From our previous experience in designing and product managing new consumer products, we're confident we'll get Tableau produced in these numbers within three months. We've planned with contingencies but there is always a chance that multiple unexpected setbacks will stack. By keeping channels open with multiple partners, we're keeping this risk to a minimum.

Distribution
We've been warned that this might become a significant challenge. Tableau works using zero electricity, so getting certifications and clearing import regulations shouldn't pose any extra problems. At any rate EU pledgers, you're all clear. We're also in touch with distributors in the US, Australia, and Asia. If you're pledging from outside these regions, we'd like to invite you to help us make sure we hit our delivery dates.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
FLYTE is a levitating light which hovers by magnetic levitation and is powered through the air. With FLYTE, we've set the lightbulb free.
                                                                                         The world moves so fast, so take a break from gravity and experience something surreal that appears suspended in time. FLYTE requires no batteries and powers light through the air via induction. 
 
MAKER KIT: Create your own levitating thingy. The FLYTE Maker Kit includes a base and a magnet with 4 ultra bright LEDs powered wirelessly via induction. Share it with your friends, or combine them to make multiple levitating light sculptures. Light will rotate slowly around the room. We can't wait to see what you'll come up with.
Designed in Sweden, the FLYTE base is made of sustainable sourced oak, ash and walnut. We want your FLYTE to look good, feel good and last a long time. We use energy efficient LEDs rated at about 50,000 hours. That's 12 hours a day for 11 years! 
Nikola Tesla's Wireless Power System
Wireless power transfer transmission has been around since the days of Nikola Tesla. With FLYTE we've packed some of Tesla's tech and combined it with magnetic levitation, opening up a magical world of possibilities. Our wireless power module transmits about 5V and is completely safe and harmless. Edison and Tesla can finally be friends.
 Power is transferred wirelessly from the base to the bulb.

How do I levitate FLYTE?
Gently lower the bulb over the center of the magnetic base. The LEDs will start to light up and you will start to feel an upward resistance. When the bulb is positioned exactly at the center of the base, you will feel a gentle release. The electro-magnets will automatically center the bulb in position. Slowly let go of the bulb and it willl lock in position, light up and rotate slowly. 

FLYTE custom series features a handmade diamond-cut wooden base. Each unit is unique and numbered, and is made in Sweden from elm wood. Get your limited edition piece crafted from designer and woodworker Dan Henriksson.
Turning on & off your FLYTE is as simple as touching the surface of the base. Light will turn on & off while the levitation will remain intact.
Our capactive touch sensor is where the magic happens. Our FLYTE switch feels effortless and smooth, just like touching wood.
Charge your smartphone...through the air.
Place your phone over the base and the built-in induction coil will transform your FLYTE into a wireless charging base station.*

 *Requires third parties accessory.

 FLYTE is the result of years of research using magnetic levitation and induction technologies.  Here are just some of the designs and iterations leading up to FLYTE.
We have secured our relations with our manufactures and ready to start the production process but in order to make this a reality, we need your help. We have moved out of the prototyping phase and are now ready to bring FLYTE to you. Back our project and be the first to experience levitating light!
Max Brightness: 60 Lumens 
Lifetime 50 000 Hours ( 22 years based on 6 hours a day)
Color Temperature Warm White / 2700-3000 Kelvin
Efficiency 16Lm/W 
Power Adapter: 15 Volts US / EU Plug / Global Voltage Compatible 100 - 240V 
Usage Indoor Use Only
FLYTE Base Dimensions: 125mm x 125mm x 27mm / (4.9 x 4.9 x 1 inches)
Weight of Base: 500 grams / 1.10 Pounds
FLYTE PREMIUM Dimensions: 200mm x 200mm x 35mm (7.9 X 7.9X 1.4 Inches) 
FLYTE Includes:
Crafted wooden base
Shatter-proof light bulb in hard plastic encasing
Low voltage power adapter (15 Volts)
FLYTE BASE
 FLYTE PREMIUM BASE

Chris Higham & Narwhal pictures, Happygoodtime productions, The Makerspark team ( David Giertta, Artur Tchoukanov, Gustaf Josefsson ), House of Radon, Grandpa.se, Anton Surtell, Sixten Frans, Daniella Rocha, MbCF, People People, Snask, Laura Tomlinson, Andreas Lindegren, Jerome and Jeff Morris.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have meticiously checked our sources and trusted manufacturers and feel we are on the right road for a successful production. That said, there are many unforeseen delays and we are working hard to minimize the risks and to bring the product to your doorstep as swiftly as possible. This is our first run of the product and naturally, delays can occur. Timing, unforeseen circumstances, delays from manufacturing, tooling, packaging and distribution are risks with launching any product. We have an excellent award-winning team behind us and hope to minimize this as much as possible and feel confident that our hard work, experience, and dedication will overcome these potential obstacles as quickly as possible.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Hi, I just go my flyte makers kit. the levitation works, but the led does not light up. what exactly do I have to do to make it work? How and where do I have to place the coil with the led bulb? regards juergen

@Radd Iyer Chill Out! What were you expecting from a "Maker's Kit?" Its for makers so you have to make something of it. I agree a simple sheet explaining the use of the circuit board and extra LEDs would be nice. But this is not rocket science for a maker! To use the "junk" as you call it, just tape the pickup coil (the copper windings) to the bottom of the levitation magnet. Let the leads wrap around the magnet to place the little circuit board on top. Now when you levitate the magnet, the single LED on the board will light up. Also as I mentioned below, that light gives you feedback about the levitation. Particularly when you are manually starting (without the co-pilot), the LED lets you know when it is actively trying to grab the magnet. If the LED goes out, don't let go!

I wish it had came with different size magnets i would 3d print a small candle stick or something cool and make it look like the light was floating off it lol also i finally got the hang of floating it with out the setup tool yay lol but you were right about lowering it rapidly!

@David Byrd - I think you are supposed to hook them up to the little circuit board. If you look at the Flyte Light Bulb, there are multiple LEDs pointing in different directions. The board has four small holes at the corners, but these don't have solder pads. So I think you need to de-solder the central LED, add some wires, and do your thing with the rest of the LEDs. I'm not sure current limiting resistors are needed or not.

@David Byrd - Simon sent me a message saying that the USB is for us to use as we see fit, to charge phones or the like.

Also as others have mentioned, lowering it rapidly helps. With the copilot ring, let it drop into the center. If the magnet slides off to one side of the ring, gently move the ring to push it back towards the center. Often I was able to get it to levitate by doing this before going manual as I described above. But if it doesn't catch after a few seconds, grab the magnet and try dropping it in again.

I agree with Alan below. Counter intuitively, placing the magnet fairly quickly seems to be the trick to levitation success. At least for me. Bringing it down as close to center as possible is also a must. You can feel the magnetic center as you place it. I guess this is where the practice Simon mentions comes in. I am now successful almost every time even without the tube. Oddly, attempting to place it slow and methodically very rarely results in success for me. So don't be shy. I suggest that if you can't place successfully it in under a second, pull it back and try it again. This is definitely very cool !!!!

campaign.story:
A BIG THANKS to all of our backers for making this campaign a wild success! If you missed our campaign, you can still get your SnapPower Chargers at www.snappower.com
SnapPower Charger Overview
Powerful 1-amp USB charger built into an outlet cover plate.
Charges any USB device (phones, phablets, tablets, hotspots, etc.) and eliminates the need for bulky wall warts. 
Installs in seconds over any standard outlet in your home. 
There’s no wiring to mess with, and no batteries to sort out. Just bring a screwdriver and a good attitude. 
For renters, this solution provides convenient wall charging that can be taken with you when you move.  If you move out, just pop the old cover back on.
Make any standard outlet in your home USB compatible...in seconds
* Not compatible with GFCI outlets
 Installation is drop-dead simple. For real. Seriously.
 Wiring is a buzzkill. The SnapPower Charger installs in literally seconds, and requires no wiring whatsoever. Here’s the play-by-play:
Simplicity makes all the difference
PLAY

Take back your outlets!
Even when charging your devices, both outlets remain open and available for other uses at all times.
Design
With custom-built components engineered to fit entirely inside the cover plate, it's the sleekest, most low profile charger around.
Its slim design allows furniture to be positioned snug against the wall. The side access to the charging port enables you to plug your USB cables in with no hassle.
No more searching for lost adapters
Unlike plug-in adapters that get shuffled around from room to room (and eventually lost), the SnapPower Charger is securely screwed to the outlet and always there when you need it.
 Charges any device from any manufacturer
Blends in with any home decor
How it works (or, the science behind the magic)
What type of outlets can be used with the SnapPower Charger?
The SnapPower Charger comes in a variety of styles and colors. The Chargers are compatible with standard duplex and decor outlets that have exposed screw terminals, regardless of the manufacturer or year. The SnapPower charger is not compatible with Ground Fault Circuit Interrupter (GFCI) outlets that are sometimes found in bathrooms. GFCI outlets do not have the required screw terminals and can be identified by the “test” and “reset” buttons located on the face of the outlet.
Compatible Outlets:
If you’re picking up what we’re putting down, help us by sharing SnapPower with your friends and family!
For the Press
If you're looking for hi-res pictures, you've come to the right spot! Just click HERE.  If you need to get in contact, feel free to email us at kickstarter@snappower.com.  

Rewards
Timeline
Can you install the SnapPower Charger upside down (with the USB port above the outlet)?  
The SnapPower Charger is designed to work in only one orientation. The USB port is designed to be installed on the same side as the ground prongs on the outlet. For example: If the ground prongs on the outlet are facing down, the Charger will need to be installed with the USB port beneath the outlet.  If the ground prongs on the outlet are facing up, then the Charger will need to be installed with the USB port above the outlet (pictured below).
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Forecast Risk
We've spent a lot of time engineering a product that meets the highest standards of performance, durability and convenience. Our manufacture has been selected and we are gearing up for production. We learned a lot from our first Kickstarter campaign and look forward to delivering once again on time. With that being said, surprises can happen and we will be sure to always be transparent and inform our backers of potential hurdles that may come up.


Supply Chain Risk
We've finalized our production schedule and plans with experienced manufacturers to ensure that the SnapPower Charger is on schedule to deliver according to our forecast. Our team is experienced in the full spectrum of the Supply Chain process. However, unexpected shortages and delays can occur when dealing with numerous components from different suppliers. If anything does come up, we will be sure to notify our backers promptly and work quickly to resolve any issues.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Get ready...we just launched our most groundbreaking product ever
updates.update_content:
Hello Backers!
Big News!  We just launched our newest, most innovative product ever on Kickstarter!
Our backers have been begging us for this product and we’re happy to announce that we’ve just launched the SnapPower ConnectLight this morning on Kickstarter.  It’s a motion activated Guidelight with a HUGE SURPRISE (you have to see it to believe it)!

updates.update_userinfo: I just launched my new Kickstarter Campaign - Get up to 66% off!
updates.update_content:
Hello Backers!
I’m extremely excited to announce that I’ve just launched my newest product on Kickstarter and that I’m offering it for 66% off the retail price for the first 500 people that buy!  Check it out here! 
It’s a reusable slide-a-part straw that gives you complete inside access for quick, easy, and thorough cleaning (no more disgusting drinking straws!).

Hello Backers!
Hope you’re having a great Friday.  As of last week, all Kickstarter orders have been shipped for backers with completed surveys!
Thank you all so much for your support with this project and for making it happen! We definitely couldn't have planned for the response we received and it was a lot of hard work and long nights to get everything produced and shipped out. We're very grateful to everyone for funding this project and for your patience with the fulfillment process.

Hello Everyone!
Hope you're all doing well and have fun plans for the weekend!  
We're emailing to let you know that as of this past Wednesday we have started shipping the SnapPower Chargers to Kickstarter Backers! Per our last email, we will be shipping all Kickstarter orders throughout the remainder of September and first part of October.  As soon as your order ships you will receive an email with a shipping confirmation and tracking number.

updates.update_userinfo: The SnapPower Charger has received UL approval
updates.update_content:
Hello Backers!
We have great news! We’ve just been informed by UL that the SnapPower Charger has passed all testing and is now UL certified. Now that this process is finalized we can start up our production lines for YOUR SnapPower Chargers! 
The first production ready Chargers should start coming off the line towards the end of August and we will be shipping the Kickstarter orders throughout the month of September and first part of October.

Hello Backers!
We're emailing to inform you that all surveys for reward selections have now been emailed out. If you have already filled out your survey, please disregard this email.
For those of you who have still not completed your survey it is very important you get them filled out as soon as possible. When the time comes to begin shipping the Chargers, we will be using the information from these surveys to decide what style and color of Chargers to ship to you along with the address you would like us to send them to.

Hello SnapPower Backers!
Recently our Kickstarter campaign wrapped up and we're incredibly happy and grateful for the amazing response we received on the SnapPower Charger. Thank you so much for your support and help in getting this new product to market. We know you’re going to love it!
Now that funding has closed, we are busy putting together a survey that will allow you to provide us with your order details (shipping info, color and style selections, etc…). We will be emailing this survey to the email address you provided us with when you placed your order on Kickstarter. Please be sure to keep an eye out for this email over the next 30 days.

Hey Everyone!
Hope you’re all having a great week! We’re reaching out to give you a quick update on how things have been moving along with the engineering and manufacturing of your Chargers. 
In our last update we informed you that we had just placed our order for the tooling. This past week the raw steel for the tooling arrived at the factory and we have begun cutting the first injection mold tools (you can see the injection mold below with the Charger indentations).

updates.update_userinfo: Big THANKS from the SnapPower Team
updates.update_content:
Hello Backers!!
  Hope you’re all doing well! We wanted to reach out to all of you and say...

@Tim Miller these are not outlets. They are covers only. They connect using springs to the tops of the screws ON your outlets. Special Al/Cu outlets still use steel screws, to the best of my knowledge. As long as they are physically in the typical screw locations, these covers have a good chance of working just fine for you. Test before you give up, but I assure you the Al/Cu will not be an issue. The physical layout of your outlets *might* but that's independent of which metal is in your wires.

So what's all the fuss? Stated 1A in the beginning. Pictures of intended plate design shown. Still backers supported a great idea. Now why the complaints. If the shoe fits--wear it. Doesn't appear to be anyone's fault but our own.

As you continue to develop products in the future, please keep in mind that many of us live in parts of the country where power outlets are installed horizontally. I would love the order guide lights for example, but the vertical orientation wouldn't work as well. Something to keep in mind.

The SnapPower Charger comes with one charging port. The redesign to accommodate two ports, additional tooling, procuring the right components and UL certification process will take some time to figure out. Because of this we we will only be offering the one port option at this time. UL certification is the most difficult obstacle to overcome when trying to introduce a second port. UL has very specific requirements for separating input voltages from USB output voltages. It is difficult to overcome this without a complete redesign and without making the design overly large.
